Text: The problem here is that people in your past seem to have diagnosed fairly normal behaviors as abnormal ones.   A behavior becomes a disorder/disease when it starts getting in the way of healthy functioning. If it gets in the way of someone being able to go to school, function socially, hold down a job, be independent, make conscious and healthy life choices etc.  It's the measure of how much it hinders you that is the issue, not how difficult it is for someone else to wrangle you as a child.   I wouldn't recommend people with schizo-affective disorder to quit their Seroquel on their own.. any more than the average kid should be on amphetamines..   I'm sorry they got it so wrong in your case.

To me it's simple. Is this emotion fucking up your life, relationships, self esteem, and is holding you back from things you want to do? In my case, bipolar disorder was. I attempted suicide twice and was hospitalized. What I saw at the hospital were not teenagers with emotions (I was a teenager too). I saw shattered lives. And inpatient did help me and many others I know, along with meds. As an adult, I still take meds (will probably take them forever) and I feel genuinely well and healthy.

So relatable, none of the shrinks ever agreed as to whether what I have is borderline personality disorder, bipolar disorder, anxiety disorder or good ol' depression. I've even had one quack tell me recently I have an untended narcissistic wound (which sure sounds like sound medical diagnosis based on available scientific evidence lol). You can imagine that the shrinks don't like it when I say that there is nothing wrong with me and that the way I am is merely a response to environmental factors (e.g. money etc). After years of putting up with the valium, seroquel, trazodone, elavil, ativan, efexor, ambien and selexa, I can safely say that you get objectively better psychiatric results from not going to the shrink and self medicating via your local liquor store and friendly neighborhood dealer. It's cheaper, comes with less side effects and means much less time in sterile waiting rooms. I don't mean to say psychiatry in general is a fraud, some people with actual conditions like hallucinations induced by schizophrenia actually need the shrinks and the drugs, but nowadays they have a habit of making each and every single negative emotion into a disorder or condition of its own.

I had a lot of difficulty going to work, getting things done, or leaving the house for a while and went to a few people for it. At one point I was diagnosed with 'Emotional ADD,' something no other therapist or psychologist has been able to define for me since then, and was prescribed adderall. I was stoked since I was pretty much trying to get that prescription because I had tried it illicitly once before and found it very... effective. It was very easy to sway the guy that direction just by looking up the specific reasons Adderall is prescribed and repeating them during our sessions. Anyway, it certainly worked at getting me productive, but I was also getting upset all of the time, my temper was so short which was weird because (not to toot my own horn) I am one of the most patient, soft spoken people I know. The new short temper I could only wield as an unruly club eventually was one of the key causes that my relationship of 5 years began to dissolve.  Of course, it turns out it was probably the relationship that got me so depressed! After the break up, I stopped taking adderall, started being able to live for myself outside of a soulless relationship, and found the freedom to explore parts of my life I had been repressing since getting into that 'lifelong' relationship at the too-young age of 20. The psychiatrist that prescribed me adderall? I'm pretty sure he was a quack. His office was in a big abandoned strip mall and it was always so scary to go to.  I've  always thought people are too quick to jump to medication instead of addressing the roots of problems. My parents sent me to therapists in elementary school to see if I had ADHD because I was smart and didn't do homework and had a hard time in class etc etc.... but it was because I was being made fun of all the time for smelling like my parent's cigarette smoke or having a cleft pallet. It had nothing to do with medication. The adults in my life just didn't want to take the time or invest the energy into getting to know me, but my parents had plenty of money to throw at medication. The guy I was dating in that long relationship was the same way, he wasn't interested in investing the time and energy into the relationship when I suggested it might be in trouble. Instead of working with me to heal things, he almost immediately decided I needed to see a therapist. He wouldn't even consider a couple's therapist, all of the fault had to be mine. I guess in the long run it got us to where we needed to be, but it was a heartbreaking realization to know you'd move mountains for a man who just can't be bothered.

My sister and I are both victims are rough childhoods and grew up with poor coping skills.  I've been on about 8 different medications to manage depression and anxiety from trauma and poverty.  Now, I've been off all medication for about 3 years and I've never felt this clear-minded and stable.  My sister, unfortunately, has been on meds since age 12 and will likely be on them for the rest of her life.  I personally know so many people that have had their lives ruined by this system that, as you said, 'medicalizes' normal emotions.  So many people can't get out of the medication cycle, and many are convinced that meds are the only thing that can help.  Some medications are legitimate but many are the result of addiction and brain-washing. Studies show that therapy is just as effective, if not more effective than medications in many cases.  I probably sound like a conspiracy theorist but I've seen the horror of this first-hand.  My heart goes out to everyone that needs to find peace <3 there are brighter days.

It's fair criticism of AA that so many refer to alcoholism as a 'disease', when the founders originally only took Dr. Silkworth's theory of 'an allergy' with a grain of salt, saying 'this theory intrigues us, as it explains many things for which we cannot otherwise account'. The line is crossed when people use labels to disavow responsibility for their behavior, and this isn't limited to just addiction. While it's true there are parts of my own psychology that have perhaps been irreversibly changed by past addiction, real recovery is at least a partial embrace of ideas espoused compellingly on page 86 of the NA basic text *...the time has come when that tired old lie, 'Once an addict, always an addict,' will no longer be tolerated by either society or the addict himself. We do recover.* source: ex-problem drinker

Since we're all sharing stories here's mine. I started hurting myself when I was about 8 years old. I beat my head on my desk and pulled my hair because I forgot to write in my planner. When I was eleven I smashed my head into a wall and tried to choke myself for forgetting the words to a song I was singing for choir competition. When I was 17 I dislocated my own jaw because I got into a disagreement with my friend Bug. These were not isolated events. These kinds of things were happening all the time when I was in school. It was always awful. I never know what would trigger a display of self harm. I didn't get help for it until after I dislocated my jaw and had to go home early from school. My anxiety and my need to be perfect and good at everything ate at me so throughly that I would seriously injure myself for no good reason. It still happens too. I got into a disagreement about trans rights with my more conservative friend on Mother's Day and when I couldn't articulate my point correctly I started punching myself in the head. I don't know if my medicine is helping me, but I sure hope it is because I can still feel the bruise on my head that I put there and it sucks.

I know this is a bit of a late response but actually in psychiatry there are no diseases there are only disorders. And a disorder is a pattern of emotions or behaviors that prevent you from participating in everyday life and cause strong distress to you. I mean of course this is still subjective but I like that it focuses more on wether people are suffering than what's 'normal'.

A short questionnaire I fill in at every GP appointment asks: 'Do you think you worry too much about things?' I respond, always, with: 'No. I think I worry just the right amount about things, thank you.' Perhaps anxiety and depression are, in fact, the only sane responses to the increasingly insane world around us.

Psychiatry is advancing pretty rapidly now, after a century of fuck-ups and dead-ends. That is partly why it got a bad reputation - it was still in the equivalent of the hacksaws and morphine stage of physical medicine for most of that time!

I'm a third year psych student. Also a human. From what I see, over medication is definitely an issue in North America for pain and psychological disorders. I question psychiatry to an extent as I'm personally a fan of working on changing thoughts and behaviors and listening over the use of pharmaceuticals. I don't deny that further help may be required for those who continue to suffer despite all other efforts made, but strongly believe that all other options should be soght out first. For example depression or anxiety could be due to poor treatment of a person, if they leave the environment and improve then did they need a drug it a change in their life? Or OCD working on reducing certain habits so the mental chatter is then reduced. Some high functioning auditory/visually hallucinating schizophrenics can go off of medication and watch others to see if the things they see are real or not. But of course these options don't work for some moderate and probably most severe cases. I like psychology it counseling over psychiatry.

At various times I've been diagnosed manic-depressive (later renamed 'bipolar disorder'), paranoid schizophrenic, schizo-dependent schizophrenic, schizotypal personality disorder, and borderline personality disorder.  (Collect them all!  Trade with your friends!)  I haven't been a consumer of psychiatric pharmaceuticals in decades and don't have any use for psychiatrists myself.

ADHD is a real thing and meds really can help with it.   WIthout question, it has been overdiagnosed in kids.  People who really do have ADHD do not respond to stimulants by feeling speedy or high (in fact, if you do, that is a sign of misdiagnosis).  I was diagnosed at age 66 for ADHD Inattentive Type, which I truly have.  But in my experience, the pendulum has swung and they no longer give out psych meds like candy.  It took months of interviews to get the prescription.  Partly it seems due to my age, as they are more concerned about cardiac issues with older people.  And it might be mainly for speed.  But I get the impression the pendulum is swinging WRT psych drugs in general.

This is a tricky thing. I like to think that I'm as anti-capitalist as they come (and, oh, irony, I'm typing this on my MacBook Pro), but I cringe whenever I hear 'for-profit' used as an argument against a thing. I'm a teacher, and I get paid for the work that I do, and I wouldn't do it if I didn't get paid; does that mean that I'm *only* in it for the money? Likewise, I have friends who work as researchers in the pharmaceutical industry, and I wouldn't be surprised if they also expected to get paid for their work. But they also do it for other reasons: they love science and chemistry and they want their knowledge and research to help people. The danger of capitalism, and where it threatens our very survival, comes from the top: not from the researchers and lab technicians, but from the CEOs and PR departments (about 50% of the cost of a drug goes into marketing, not further research), who push products on overworked doctors, or push lobbyists on ambitious lawmakers. But yeah, brain chemistry is extremely complicated, and psychiatric care is driven almost entirely by self-reporting of the patient, so it necessarily requires the doctor and the patient to work together toward a treatment. Add to that that most psychiatric drugs are specifically designed to work slowly, to avoid dependency, so it can take time, sometimes months, for the drug to take effect. In the meantime, the body needs to adjust to the new chemicals being introduced, which necessarily results in side-effects. It took me months to get to the dose I'm currently at, and I'm not all better yet, but I DO know that if I hadn't gone and talked to my doctor, I would be dead now. And with all the shit that's been going on in my life these past few months, I'm definitely glad I'm on medication.

In the interest of clarity I'd like to add that the reason most antidepressants list suicidal ideation as a side effect is that they typically increase motivation before they have any affect on mood. As a result of this, depending on where a person is in their experience of this, there is a risk that they can get the motivation to act on this feeling before the feeling lifts. It's important that clinicians and patients work together to decide what the best course of action is and when and how to implement it.

Making a disagnosis isn't passing a value judgement - it's based, among other things, on functionality. Do the individual's thoughts / emotions / behaviors obstruct their work, social relationships and everyday activities? This is a lot different that characterising them as 'abnormal' based purely on statistical abnormality.

While I completely agree that people are overdiagnosed and overmedicated, the primary message seems dangerous. Perhaps I'm misunderstanding the point. To me, it seems like you're saying that psychiatry for the most part is ineffective treatment. Bipolar and psychotic disorders absolutely require medication. Other disorders occur on a spectrum, and the treatment varies. Psychiatry isn't perfect, and I strongly believe that a psychologist, in most situations, should be the primary treatment. It does have its place, though.  Edit: you asked about experiences, so..I was like you in high school, overmedicated, they didn't know what was wrong (mostly because I didn't communicate what was tormenting me..an eating disorder, an abusive relationship, trauma, and tormenting intrusive thoughts). It easily led to depression, anxiety, and rage. Adulthood, substance abuse was my way of self medicating. I also had some mania with psychosis. I had severe OCD. Like shit you see on documentaries. Very suicidal. Panic attacks. I was raped and sexually abused a handful of times, so I developed ptsd. Throughout my journey, I have off and on had therapy and medication. Now..I'm ok. I get suicidal sometimes. I have anxiety and some obsessive compulsiveness. I think if I didn't have treatment I wouldn't be alive. My journey has been rocky and imperfect. Professionals are limited in their abilities, considering how little we truly know about the mind. I think they do their best, and I do my own research on treatments, too, and assist them in giving me the best treatment. I'm not happy, though. Maybe in the future.

*Part 1: Depression* I struggled with depression for most of my life, starting from about when I was in middle school, around 1997 when I was about 12 years old.  In my case, it _was_ a serious disease that produced some very maladaptive thoughts and kept me from being able to feel contented for a long time.  This was exacerbated by the difficulty I had interacting with other people, which I later found out was undiagnosed Asperger's syndrome.  More on that below.  *What didn't work* Regarding medication, I had already tried therapy for my depression, but no one with whom I spoke really seemed to do any good.  They just took my time away from work and charged me hundreds of dollars, and I was making zero progress.  When I went to a general practitioner and got prescribed anti-depressants, I thought I was on a better track, but it was equally useless for me, if not possibly worse.  The first reaction I remember having to the anti-depressant Wellbutrin was anger.  Just blind, unthinking, vague anger at nothing at all.  My doctor was not a particularly helpful one, either.  She would _not_ let me off those drugs.  If I told her that they were not helping, she would say that was proof that I still needed to be on them so that they could work.  If I told her that they _were_ helping and that I was feeling _better_ now, she said that was evidence that they were helping, so I needed to keep taking them.  I was literally trying to find what I could possibly say to her that would get her to let me off of them.  Apparently, the magic phrase was: 'I lost my job and with it my health insurance, so I cannot afford these drugs anymore.  Tell me how to step down off them safely.'  I experienced no noticeable withdrawal, which reinforced my suspicion that the drugs had done me no good in the first place.  *What DID work* YouTube.  Would you believe it?  Tens of thousands of dollars wasted on doctors and drugs, and what gave me the right angle to fix myself was a pair of YouTube videos: 'The Tetris Effect- Train Your Brain!' followed by 'Why Happiness is the New Productivity (The Story of Mindvalley) | Vishen Lakhiani'.  Part of what locked me into my vicious cycle of depression was a pair of beliefs.  The first was that I could do nothing to affect my own mind, to change the thoughts that I had.  The 'Tetris Effect' video showed me that I could change my mind.  The other harmful belief was that I needed to beat myself up for every imperfection in order to motivate myself to be better.  The 'Happiness is ... Productivity' video showed me that the opposite was true.  I decided to give it a shot, and spend a few minutes every day finding something genuinely positive to say about myself, to look to the future, to find something about which to be grateful.  It was awkward and clunky at first, like learning to play a musical instrument.  It felt a bit insincere, but I trained my brain.  With practice, I got better.  Nowadays, I think of myself as having 'depression in remission'.  It's sort of like having herpes.  It doesn't flare up often, but I will always have it.  But that is okay.  I have the tools to deal with it, and even at its worst, I know that I will recover.  My default is no longer self-loathing.  My default is positive, and that makes all the difference.  *Part 2: Asperger's Syndrome* As I said before, I had a very hard time relating to people.  Many people with Asperger's syndrome have ways of handling it much better than I did, but in my case, the lack of empathy and ability to relate to other humans led me to some pretty scummy ideas, speech, and behavior.  I was _not_ a good guy in high school, I am ashamed to admit.  I did not realize it at the time, though.  I was a total 'Nice Guy(tm)' incel asshole, though those particular terms were not familiar to me at the time.  I was very stunted in my development of social skills.  I think part of that was because no one taught me social skills.  I was expected to pick them up naturally the way that neurotypical people did, but I was not well-adapted to learn that way.  On the contrary, I was repeatedly exposed to messages like 'Break the mold', 'Don't be a conformist', 'Be yourself', et cetera.  These messages are great for people who feel undue pressure to conform, but in my personal case, I actually needed to hear the opposite message, because I was interpreting these messages as 'Ignore other people', 'Their feelings are irrelevant', 'The only truth comes from within your own mind', et cetera.  This was not diagnosed in me until much later in my life, so for a long time, I had no idea that there was even anything wrong with me (aside from the depression).  On the contrary, I sort of thought that there was something wrong with _EVERYONE ELSE,_ and I hated it.  Eventually, though, I realized that, if I were going to succeed in 'real life' (life after academia), I needed to learn how to get along with people.  *What DID work* I tried going to public places and sitting and watching and listening to people as much as I could to try to mimic humans, as though to see if I could trick them into thinking that I was a fellow human just like them.  It was a fair start.  Later, I attended a set of 'Authentic Relating' games/experience in weekend classes.  This came with exercises in interacting with people, including an 'empathy' game, that I found extremely helpful.  Eventually, I listened to the audio book version of 'How to Win Friends and Influence People'.  I listened to it twice.  It was an incredibly helpful body of work for teaching me how to be a social being, and I strongly recommend it.  *Conclusion* So, basically, thank you for sharing your journey.  I wanted to share my own, too, so that anyone struggling with similar feelings and issues who has not tried those things that worked for me might try them and see if they work for them.  Also, to other viewers, let me know what you think about this, or how this relates to your own journey.  Best wishes!

So, this video kind of inspired me to try psychiatric drugs for my depression/anxiety (I know that wasn't really your point, but...). They made me so constipated and bloated for a month I had to get off of them (I took Lexapro for one week and mirtazapine for 3 weeks). I know the drugs work really well for some people, but I'd advise anyone thinking of trying them to pay attention to what they do to your stomach... they have anti-cholinergic effects, which means they disrupt the brain chemical that helps your bowels move. Now I'm thinking my issue might not be something related to serotonin, but maybe dopamine or the acetyl-choline system? There are some places (naturopaths) you can actually get neurotransmitter tests done and they will tell you what chemicals your brain is having problems producing.  On the other hand, I think life does have a strong effect on your mind... if you're not in a good place in your life, you're not going to be happy even if your brain chemicals are functioning properly.

Problem with SSRIs are overprescription. They work against severe depression as measured on the icd-10 scale, meaning having all three primary symptoms plus almost all secondary symptoms. In general that means being depressed to such a degree that you can not function on a daily basis.   Also, the systematic review raising doubt about how effective SSRIs commited the methodology mistake of including all clinically research on SSRIs, including the first approval studies that didn't really look at the clinically effects of the drug, but rather just focused on 'do people die if taking this'(The drug was developed back in 70's and the requirements for clinical approval and clinically experiments was a lot different).

I was diagnosed with ADD, Aspergers and pathological anxiety. The Aspergers one... I don't believe it that much. I always have been strange, but I never felt anything towards it. The ADD... I personally think it all has just one root: The anxiety.   My anxiety really blocked my life. There were tons of things I just couldn't do because of anxiety. And most of them were quite simple. I knew this was uncommon once I started to see others. The grand revelation was when I talked with a biologist who had a different approach towards anxiety and we talked about it for some time.  What has helped me though, besides the single pill I have to take, has been to change my life in a positive way. I think of my anxiety as a bad stomachache. You can prevent stomachaches by eating healthy and mantaining good health. Same goes for anxiety: There are activities that can help me a lot. Excercise has been fundamental for me. And a lot of spiritual texts too (although I'm a non-believer, being an intellectually curious person has driven me to read more mind-related topics in a variety of perspectives).

I know this video is like 3 years old now but fuck it: I tell this story at literally every opportunity because it's necessary. I'm 22, and last year I got diagnosed with ADHD and put on what we call Dexxies in Australia (Adderall in the US). I got diagnosed after taking a pill full of speed at a music festival and it made me sit down and concentrate for hours instead of dance. I had been tested for ADHD in preschool - the school's decision, not my parents - and the psychiatrist said I needed to be in a more structured environment so my parents moved me from Montessori to public school and that was that. But, from the time I was 16 to the time I was 21, my life began to fall apart - I couldn't concentrate while driving so would have minor accident after minor accident, which ended up with my parents spending hundreds and hundreds of dollars at the panelbeater. My social life was slipping, I could't hold down a job. My life has changed so much since starting meds - I went from failing uni to getting HDs, I have a job, I have stable relationships and feel pretty much fine all the time. So like, obviously this is a good thing, right? Well, Contra mentioned the rage and despair she got from the meds, and honestly I feel the same way. At the end of each day I'm worn out, I have the shits with everyone and I basically go hide in my room to die for a few hours. There's stuff that helps this obviously - eating healthy, various vitamin supps, exercise (which is realistically the biggest help for ADHD but again something made very difficult by capitalism and colonialism), having a supportive network of neurodivergent queers and weirdos who 'get it'. I also have done a lot of learning about ADHD and have come to the conclusion that: if I didn't live in a colonialist-capitalist world, my ADHD would never have been a problem for me really. They say ADHD is the brain of a hunter, and honestly if I could run around in the forest all day picking mushrooms and fruits I think that pretty much every single one of my problems would be solved - I wouldn't have to make myself fit around an education system that wasn't made with me in mind, I wouldn't have to bend myself into a job market that doesn't want me to succeed in it, I wouldn't have to wear the burden of ableism that destroys my self-confidence and turns everything into an unwinnable competition. But I can't do that just yet, so I've settled for dexxies, endless cups of coffee and chugging down berocca and about 15 litres of water every day to mitigate the side effects. Realistically I just can't live without it, but it's also a lot better than being so angry and frustrated at my inability to do pretty much anything right in the world and fucking up everything I do because I can't remember what happened 5 minutes ago. And let's be clear: I still feel like that most or all of the time, but at least the medication gives me the resilience to be able to continue to keep trying every day.  I also have an OCD diagnosis but I only got it after like 10 years of having massive meltdowns if I thought there were germs on me and picking at my own skin. For that I was given a drug called fluvoxamine which worked but also worsened my executive function to the point where I basically spent all day happily lying in bed until someone would make the very reasonable suggestion that I get out of bed, and I just got the shits again.  I get so anxious every time I see a video like this, or someone starts up the 'let's criticise psychiatry' thing because I think so often it just doesn't center around the people who are going to those people for help and why, it ends so often with like the 'sheeple who take too many pills' getting the blame. I don't think that was done in this video, maybe because it came from someone who's been on the Magic Roundabout of the therapist's office before, but I think that this is something that ends up inhibiting every discussion on the topic, and probably also because when you have ADHD, you can't leave the house without some fuckwit coming up to you and going 'hey did you know ADHD isn't real it's just society don't take your meds just do more exercise, something somethign CBD oil just work harder and concentrate more you can do it.' It's infuriating.  Bottom line in response to this video - maybe I'm not really sick objectively speaking, but I'm sick subject to the pressures of colonialism and capitalism, and psychiatry is more or less the only avenue of tangible help and survival I have in this situation and I'm going to use that option until such a point where I no longer need to.

I think what sometimes is overlooked when seeking mental help is that finding the appropriate professional is key. Just because someone has all the credentials and experience necessary doesn't mean they're the right doctor for you. I tried going on medication for my depression and while it made the horrible sense of dread and numbness more bearable, it also made me withdrawn and leveled out my emotions. What so far has worked for me is finding a therapist that specializes in DBT and going off the meds. The therapy has helped me build resiliency to the depressive and anxious episodes without the medications (which posed other health complications) and I am better able to manage my mental health. Good luck to everyone else out there dealing with mental illness or otherwise going through a shitty time. You are worth putting the time and effort into yourself to get better. Peace.

A good therapist or psychiatrist is interested in one of two things. Primarily what the client thinks is problematic in their life and how well they see the problem brought by their response pattern. Many therapist and psychiatrist who work with children and adolescents did not specialize in that population. They aren't great (in my experience) at understand developmental difference in cognition, emotional expression and abstraction.   Very often when working with teenagers in particular, you have a person with noticeably problematic behavior pattern which is largely ignored because trying to directly resolve the problem is too scary or the reward is to abstract to understand. An example would be a 16 year old who smokes weed because he thinks he is having fun, but clearly is trying to avoid the emotional neglect at home. Or a 14 year old who is cruel and mean to any person who attempts an intimate relationship for fear of abandonment. These cases prompt and ugly questions: Is it better to respect the client and allow them to spiral out of control until they are ready to seek help (damage being done) or to force and intervention that robs autonomy but could help? Its never easy to tell, I have times when I muscled my way into a kids inner problems and he tearfully thanked me and times where I felt I was just pushing the kid too hard and making him hate me.

I've been diagnosed with a few of these same things. Sometimes I legitimately needed help, other times no so much.  Lexapro was useless but I think Zoloft may have helped me? Not sure...  Seroquel, Zyprexa, and all other anti-psychotics are the fucking devil and you should NEVER take them unless you are so detached from reality that you are actively hurting yourself and other people. Otherwise, the side-effects are just not worth it. Not to mention, the withdrawals were as bad as anything I've ever experienced (which is a lot) and lasted much longer than coming off any other drug. Imagine all the scary shit you've ever heard or seen about drug withdrawals and seroquel will give it to you while you stay awake for a week straight or more (literally completely awake to the point where it's really fucking creepy). And if you never actually had any auditory or visual distortions/hallucinations before you went on anti-psychotics, you will after! At least when you quit heroin you can reasonably expect to feel somewhat better by the end of a typical work week, but with seroquel you will still be shivering uncontrollably, unable to sleep, with seriously evil shit going on in your peripheral vision with no end in sight. All for a drug that doesn't even get you high.  Klonopin is pretty cool until you have to take about 8mg at a time to feel anything. Honestly, I didn't think coming off that stuff was as bad as a lot of the horror stories I read about benzo withdrawal. Still was not pleasant to stop, but to this day benzos and opiates are the only drugs that ever alleviated my constant boiling feeling of anxiety let alone the panic attacks that felt like heart attacks bad enough to literally bring me to my knees and sometimes lose consciousness amid feelings of pure irrational terror and severe physical pain at least a few times a week. I guess I should meditate about that or something?  Adderall was never prescribed to me but I did a bunch anyway. No complaints, but it's just not on the same level as meth.  Alcohol is honestly pretty lame as far as drugs go. Obviously this doesn't stop me from drinking but I don't really enjoy it. I used to be a very heavy drinker just because alcohol is so easily available when you hate having feelings but these days I hardly ever drink and never unless somebody invites me to.  The longest I've ever spent in a psychiatric institution in one stretch was a little over a week and honestly I fucking loved it. Not even kidding, it was a great experience. Everyone I met in there was really cool and I was totally fine with the adult day care vibe of the whole thing. All the rules and regulations didn't really bother me either, in fact it was pretty fun to violate them just to see what would happen. I was never bad enough to require a dose of ass juice (This is when the dudes in scrubs wrestle you to the ground and stick a syringe filled with thorazine and lorazepam in the easiest target, usually your ass, hence the name) but I did spend some time in the quite room, which just like it sounds is basically a more luxurious version of solitary confinement. My one real complaint is that they never let us watch One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest because it would have been too upsetting for some people. They never considered that other people might find nonstop gameshows and football upsetting but whatever. When I found out they had a smart tv with netflix I almost led an insurrection to demand my special request be met but that didn't work. It was fun though, and leaving that place was pretty sad because I had no friends outside and you just don't really speak to people you meet in psych wards in the outside world (unwritten rule I guess).

I want to share my experience of psychiatry. First of all, I'm from Switzerland and there, every medicals appointments is refund. I started getting bad when I was around 15. I had a massive depression who slowly became a chronic, irrational anxiety. I was afraid of pretty much everything, like going out etc. I was persuaded to be physically sick all the time. I spend hours to diagnosed myself every deseases possibles and destroyed my spleen by taking every day medications in the illusion to cure all those. So I've seen my doctor and ask her to make me a lots of blood tests etc to see what sickness I had. The results fall and it turned out that I was perfectly fine... At least physically. I couldn't believe it. She had the intelligence to ask me: 'Have you considered to see a psychologist or psychiatrist?' I realised at this moment that it was exactly what I wanted, I just needed someone to tell me. So I met this woman, a psychiatrist. I'm 21 now and I still see her, but I think not for long because I feel fine. I mean I feel as fucked up than everyone else. I guess I've been very lucky to fall on such a good doctor who always been so emphatic and human. I'm not saying that it saves my life, because probably not, but it made it bearable. And that's much that I could hope when I was 15

Nah. Allow this one. I'm speaking from a perspective of someone who has never had (at least a diagnosed) mental issue, but I think your prevaricating and non-conclusion are both deeply unhelpful.   Mental health is a sprawling issue. It's one we don't fully understand, but we do know that those people (your parents and doctors) were just trying to help you. You mention 5 diagnoses as if that's a bad thing - for all you know, the brain changes. Maybe you had 5 separate issues at different times. Maybe you needed 8 types of meds. Maybe more. What I hear from people with mental health problems is that finding the right blend is difficult. That doesn't surprise me given the number/balance of neurotransmitters in the brain.   I'd say almost any medical diagnosis begins with 'This person feels they're sick enough to be in my office right now', so they're gonna take you seriously and address you as if you need help rather than turfing you out. It always comes from a place of 'How can I help this person?' but you're making out that it's a money-making scam! Shame on you.   I notice that you hit the 'drug research is funded by drug companies' note.  Yeah, no shit. As opposed to the Boy Scouts or your second favourite youtuber funding the necessary research? It costs about a billion dollars to get a drug to market. Obviously drug companies fund drug research! Who else is gonna? It might sound scary to some but they do it to a strict set of standards.   You say it works about as well as placebos but I doubt that's true.  And even if they worked only 1% better, that's still 1000 people they help per 100k with mental health issues. Given the rate and prevalence of mental health issues, I'd say that it's worth it.   So in conclusion; I'm super sorry there wasn't one pill that helped you personally immediately, but an 8 minute video (minus 30 seconds of stigmatising mental health issues with bits of octopus) on psychiatry does a disservice to a field people don't understand well as it is and carries a certain stigma, but none the less helps countless people.

Adderall is not like high grade crystal meth, it doesnt cross the blood brain barrier as effectively. The entire point of meth, is the methylation of the amphetamine molecule so that it can use the meth group as what can be thought of as a 'key' to cross the blood brain barrier more effectively. This may not seem that important but this increase in uptake changes the effects of the drug. They are similar but its fairly different effect, can be compared to moprhine and heroine, which similarly, heroin is a form of morphine with a diaethyl group which lets it cross the blood brain barrier more effectively.   Aphetamine doesnt get produced much in the US as a recreational drug because the overwhelming supply of the pharmaceutical racemic or at least a mixture of L/R isomers. But in Europe, its very very popular, and adderall is not over prescribed, so L isomer speed is very very very popopular.   Speed or aphetamine is a lot less euphoric and easier to do things on than the much higher dose obtained from meth.   The new DSM improved a lot of your complaints. Check it out.

I have GAD and depression, and take an SSRI for it. This has made a really positive difference in my life, but I was also cautious about the medication option - I went to a therapist, who sent me to a doctor after working with me for a few months, the doctor gave me some suggestions for non-medicinal alternatives (exercise etc) with the instruction to come back if things got worse. Well, things got worse, and eight months later I went on an SSRI and the difference a few weeks on the medication made in my life was drastic. I've since been off the drug for a couple years (pregnancy and SSRIs don't always go well together) and then got back on it when my ability to manage my anxiety and depression without the medication kind of went out the window. The dosage I'm on doesn't eliminate all the anxiety or depression, but it does mitigate it to the point where I can manage it and don't feel like crap all the time. But this requires regular appointments with my doctor every few months to check in and being aware of things that can exacerbate the problems and aware of useful coping mechanisms. Given that my emotional state through much of my childhood, teens, and young adulthood were pretty textbook GAD with a side of depression, even though it took until I was almost 24 before I finally got a diagnosis and drugs, I'm pretty sure that this is just how my brain is. I'm probably always going to need a little help to keep the anxiety from running my life, and I'm okay with that now.

As someone who was put on several medications at once at the age of twelve, with little to no understanding of what that meant, I definitely have an aversion to psychopharmacology and psychiatrists (even though I one day hope to be a PhD clinical/research psychologist).  It might just be my foggy memory of a chaotic childhood, but I don't remember the concept of side effects being adequately explained to me initially, nor the idea that I didn't have to take drugs the rest of my life.  I went into it with blind trust in the psychiatrist, who I have reason to believe was possibly incentivized by drug companies.    If I could talk to that doctor now as a competent, more educated adult, I would ask him why he put me on Seroquel, an antipsychotic, telling me that it would help my insomnia (drowsiness is a side effect of Seroquel, but not why you prescribe it).  The other major side effect of Seroquel was increased appetite, and as a teenage girl going through puberty with an already increased appetite and developing body, you can imagine how much frustration and shame I experienced.  I had an appetite that I couldn't satisfy, gained tons of weight, got stretch marks, hated my body, and had no outlet for these issues.  No, just other women lecturing me on the importance of portion control.  I definitely think some psychiatrists are too quick to diagnose and medicate patients, and children and adolescents require particular caution.  I was anti-medication for several years because of my negative experiences with meds and doctors, but I eventually realized that that stance was merely another manifestation of my black and white thinking.

Therapy, if done right, can be a mirror to compare how your mind works to others, to see if how you process the world is reasonably close to others. There probably is an objective reality, but none of us can truly see it; and none of us can truly 'see' how we process reality and information from inside our own minds.  I too am ADHD, and suffer depression after a back issue caused prolonged insomnia that seems to have caused some damage. In grade school through highschool, my treatment wasn't based on drugs, but instead working with SPED teachers and therapists to develop skills and practice techniques to compensate for my issues.  As someone who has been forced to realize my family and I are all hoarders, I am again seeking help to figure out where our minds don't process things in a sane way, and then develop skills and practice techniques to compensate for that issue. To put this in perspective, the reasonable and legitimate fear of loosing a bill, and thus incuring a late payment, has caused my father to pile all the bills into an ungodly mess that guarantee bills get lost and late payments are incurred. Something is indeed wrong with his mind that he is failing to see the forest through the trees: a pill won't fix that, but perhaps training and cognitive behavioral therapy could make the necessary adjustment in his reasoning so he will behave in a way that is more likely to result in his goals. From within my own mind, it is hard to figure out what exactly is wrong with me so as to cause my messes.  That said, you are right: prescription drugs are over prescribed, and the true causes of mental issues and the effects of said drugs are not understood enough for their common use.

In terms if your experience with psychiatry is probably contributed lot by the point you first raised. You were from a middle class background with parents who probably had very good health insurance who didn't know what was the normal spectrum of child and teen behaviour. So they take you to a psychiatrist and since the US medical system is highly influenced by $$ and your had top health insurance the psychiatrist who is probably getting kickbacks in some form or another prescribes you unnecessary  medication. Had your parents not have health insurance/were poor/were not white you probably would have been sent on your way with a they'll grow out of it at best or a they're heading for prison at worst.   For many who are suffering crippling mental illness in the US who don't have health insurance they are very likely to not be diagnosed, end up in the prison system, self medicate or even if diagnosed struggle to recive the psychiatric or psychological help they need. It's a fucked system that can screw you either way.   Another complication is the gender/age/race etc biases in terms of diagnosis. If a particular disorder is generally thought of as affecting only one population e.g white middle class teenage girls with eating disorder or white boys with autism this results in mis/un diagnosis for many who don't fit the sterotype e.g males, poor, adults, ppl of colour with eating disorders and girls, adults diagnosed with depression/gastrointestinal issues/obeasity and ppl of colour with autism diagnosed with bipolar, OCD, shy, depression and anxiety or not at lol.  In addition US treatment is more likely to focus on providing medication rather than the psychological therapy needed. Medication is often crucial as it provides a base of being able to function enough to be able to do therapy and work on strategies to treat or at least cope with mental illness.   In terms of what defines a mental illness and pathology of normal emotions a good psychiatrist/psychologist will only diagnose someone with a mental illness if it is detrimental to social occupational and emotional functioning in multiple environments and creates distress to an individual. It's healthy to have a wide variety of emotions including sadness, anger and anxiety. It's only when these get in the way of someone living their lives that it becomes a problem that requires treatment.   Unfortunately due to the reasons above this is not straightforward as there as so many influences that can steer it awry. Ultimately tho psychiatry and psychology is crucial for many to be able to be able to survive and even thrive despite often debilitating illnesses.

First of all, mental illnesses are not _just_ abnormal thought patterns, they have other debilitating symptoms, some of them even physical. For example, anxiety and depression are not only overthinking stuff and being sad, but they are also the inability to focus, insomnia, panic attacks, pain, exhaustion, etc. You may procrastinate brushing your teeth and getting to the shower for days or your whole body may shake with fear you do not consciously experience. I understand your concern about overdiagnosis and misdiagnosis but those two evils co-exist with the third one, which is underdiagnosis and lack of treatment. If I had access to the right treatment years ago, I would have a different teenagehood and probably wouldn't have to build my life from scratch in my early twenties. Now, I am years behind my peers when it comes to formal education, social skills, and experience. _Well, it's also possible I would have a different story with the same ending -- I don't know and the history knows no 'ifs'._

I started taking SSRI (Zoloft) when I was over 30, not from a psychiatrist, but from my endocrinologist, who suspected I had long term depression. It hasn't been a perfect solution, but overall I'm happy with the results. I feel much more fully myself on them.

With you, you probably had gender dysmorphia, but that's not what the doctor is funded to treat, so you can only be treated for depression, bipolar disorder, and schizophrenia, because those are more directly debilitating and well funded by insurance companies.  So like psychiatry is real, but money is the realest.

Psychiatry has been part of my life as far back as I can remember; I've been in and out of therapy since childhood and taking medication for my diagnoses of OCD, Tourette's, ADHD, anxiety and depression.  My mother was a professor of psychology, so I feel lucky to have someone in my life who could identify that I had mental issues from an early age and was able to find help for me.  My behavior was very textbook to those conditions, so looking back I don't think I was misdiagnosed, but I do have concerns that, were someone else in my position, surrounded by councilors and psychologists, someone would be a hammer looking at all my problems like nails.  The field of psychiatry is ultimately a very important boon for humanity, but it lies at a very weird and dangerous intersection between empiricism and subjectivity.  Everyone's case is unique down to a biological level and reacts to the same drugs and therapies in very different ways.  You're right that it's very easy to get the diagnosis you want, and we may be subconsciously attuned to think we have a problem, especially if it seems to explain what we see as moral failings in ourselves, and for some of those problems medication seems to be the best course of action.  The best thing you can do honest as possible about your symptoms rather than trying to seek a diagnosis.  Try to get a second or third opinion if you can; not all psychiatrist's experiences are the same.

There's a reason that the things you were diagnosed with are termed disorders and not diseases. A disorder requires the condition to have a negative impact on the person's quality of life.   As someone with adhd and is medicated for it, I feel that it is irresponsible to further the common misconceptions held by the general public. Adderall is not the only medication available and not all adhd medication are stimulants.   While the main ingredient of adderall and meth are both amphetamines, they are chemically different, altering their effect. It is similar to how methanol and ethanol are both alcohols and only differ by a carbon but methanol will make you go blind. However, I believe that meth can be used as treatment, in the form of desoxyn(?). A therapeutic dose of adderall and other adhd medication is much lower (and safer) than a recreational dose. The medication I take is vyvanse which metabolises into the main ingredient of adderall so its release is slower and smoother. I do not crash as it wears off.  Medication affects different people in different ways. What should have happened in your case is that your doctor should have switched your medication or tried a lower dose.   You also bring up the common adhd stereotype of the 8 year old boy who can't sit still. This is the most visible example of adhd and I wouldn't be surprised if young boys were overdiagnosed. It's definitely possible that you were misdiagnosed. Adhd is actually underdiagnosed in girls and adults (you don't grow out of it). I was not diagnosed until I was 15 because it didn't occur to anyone that I, a wellbehaved and smart girl could possibly have it, even though I never did homework, constantly forgot things, had another disorder that has incredibly high comorbidity, zoned out constantly and was often late. I hated myself until *I* came across a list of symptoms. No one, not my parents, not my teachers, not my coaches and not my doctors picked it up because I didn't fit that fucking stereotype. It took a year for my mum to make an appointment with the gp who somewhat reluctantly referred me to a specialist. Ten minutes into my first appointment, the adhd specialist said that I probably had it and I was diagnosed 6 months later.  The abuse and distrust of adhd medication makes it difficult for the people who really need it to get access. Sorry about the rant.

I feel the drug issue is mostly a USA problem (for as far as I am aware based on several accounts of situations like this). Here in the Netherlands, drugs are only used as a temporary symptom suppressor to help you get on with life if your conditions are so debilitating you cannot do without. The keyword there is temporary, you are supposed to wean off them as your therapy progresses. All I had for my anxiety as beta blockers that I would take only on particularly stressful days, as for my SO with PTSD they only receive non-additive meds that help him sleep (meds that are usually used for people with epilepsy, so no melatonin). I have now been free of beta blockers for two years, my partner is still working on their issue. But then again, this could be just us being 'lucky' with the good mental health care we received.

This is plain wrong; anti-depressants do work better than placebos. Though these medications do have side-effects which should be weighed according to how desperately you need or want them. I know a fair amount about anti-psychotics, as I was blessed with the wonderful personal experience of what it is like to undergo acute psychosis. I've been on three so far, they all work the same (dopamine agonists), clozapine, aripiprazole, and seroquel (otherwise marketed as quietiapine in the UK). They all share similar side-effects with death actually being pretty high risk in the case of anti-psychotics.  You have similar things to anti-depressants like lowered mood, increased suicidal ideation (though you should report it), sickness, etc. There is also a diabetes issue with them, those taking them tend to go on to develop diabetes at a higher rate. But this is all weighed next to feeling like you're actually on the Earth and not being tortured in a dimension that is equivalent to most graphical depictions of hell.  Want to feel like your brain is being ripped out of your skull whilst you get to watch with an audience taunting you? Psychosis! Sometimes death is preferable.

As someone currently in an abnormal psychology class I agree that stigmatizing these conditions is not only harmful, but disingenuous. My teacher has made sure to emphasize that many conditions are just certain expressions of normal human emotions and that having the symptoms of a certain condition does not mean you necessarily have it. An aspect of mental illness we've been emphasizing is maladaptiveness, which is when the condition negatively impacts your life. In my opinion, the OCD diagnosis you got was uncalled for on that principle alone.   Psychiatry is a very complex discipline that can be subjective, which is why getting a good psychiatrist is so important should you need one. I was also diagnosed with ADD and am currently on medication for it, but meds were not the first thing we tried. We tried therapy first and when that didn't work we resorted to meds. I think it's important for psychiatrists to advocate for a variety of treatment options and to only resort to medicating patients when they need to. There are many different approaches to psychology and the biological approach is just one of them.   I'd suggest anyone who is wary of medication first try a psychologist rather than a psychiatrist. Psychologists cannot legally prescribe medication because they lack a medical degree. There are many therapists that are psychologists rather than psychiatrists. Honestly, I just use my psychiatrist to get my meds. If I ever felt like therapy would help I'd go to a psychologist instead.

There is an unfortunate tendency to medicalising behaviours and characteristics which do not fit in with cultural norms or expectations, and either thinking of them as something to be treated or smoothed out or got rid of. I am probably on the autistic spectrum. I never bothered getting a diagnosis partly because I am not sure how it would help me in my life- I mean, are people suddenly going to start understanding me better and accepting me for who I am when I have a diagnosis like that? I doubt it. I also have suffered for years form severe depression and feel over medicalised already. And I can't say that having a diagnosis of depression means people treat me better when they find me a bit odd or grumpy or something, or understand me better or give a flying fuck about how I feel, or are at all careful about how they behave towards me. In fact, people often think it means I am an easy target. Besides, I like the way my brain works. I know it gives me a different perspective on the world. Granted a perspective a lot of people have trouble getting, but I think it's really important we don't all have brains which work the same way, or we'd all just stay the same and never develop. I have wondered about trans people and the different ways they have of seeing things, and if only they could get past constantly having to fight to exist they might be able to make a great contribution to humanity and our understanding in general. I am pleased to see it in Contrapoint's videos. Not that I want to romanticise trans people's brains and assume they all have some higher understanding, any more than I would like people to romanticise my depression the way mental illnesses often are. I just feel we are missing out on valuable alternative ways of thinking because it is so hard for trans people to just exist in this world.  The problem with psychiatry is it is very influenced by what is considered acceptable in the current culture and the over reliance on drugs. As someone who has suffered from severe depression I would not say drugs are ineffective, I know I have needed them at times. My bigger problem has been the over reliance on drugs and lack of interest in trying to understand or help beyond that. Like, somehow taking some pills is supposed to fix my life and if it doesn't that's my fault rather than the result of problems of wider society, which, of course, are much harder to fix.

The main problem with therapists and 'mental health professionals' in general is not that the scientific research they rely on is bad, but rather that they do not follow any established scientific procedure in their *practice* (ie in reaching a diagnosis and deducing the underlying cause, if we assume that it even needs to be 'deduced'). When dealing with a patient, they come up with a plausible theory based on pattern recognition (which is notoriously flawed - humans often see patterns that are not there) and then look for evidence to *support* their theory, which is the opposite of good scientific practice: you're supposed to test your theory by looking for evidence to falsify it, and checking other alternatives. In fact, once they've come up with a theory, anything that the patient says is distorted to fit that theory, and contrary evidence is rationalised or overlooked. Most doctors other than psychiatrists don't do that, because they tend to deal with conditions for which there exists more solid evidence, so their experience and training has cultivated good scientific habits in them. Psychiatrists stubbornly stick to their theories.

Lexapro (an SSRI) has been a life saver for me. I'd suffered through major depression untreated for years. When I couldn't do it anymore I asked my mom if I could see a doctor and she took me to a psychiatrist. I was afraid of psychiatry and what they would do to me.   I was prescribed the lowest dosage of lexapro they made at my mothers insistence.   24hrs after taking my first dose I had an extreme rush. I was euphoric. I'd never felt so godly happy. That faded quickly and over the months and years my mood has stabilized. I'm still depressed, but no longer suffer like I did before.

So few people are talking about diet (how your OWN gut reacts to food) and psychological health still. Functional medicine has helped me more than anything else. Probably saved my life. There's false marketing in that world too, but mostly you just have to listen to your own body.

I am able to relate to you on many levels. It is almost like looking at a person I could be had I made a few different choices in my life. I just graduated with a bachelors of Art in Philosophy and am currently enrolled in a Master of Arts in English program. I have struggled with whether I am an autogynaphile who is only interested in female gender expression because I witnessed my father cross-dress as  child, or if I have sincere interest, at least one that isn't purely motivated by sex. On top of this I have a history with depression and self-deprecating thoughts and have been institutionalized because of suicide attempts and psychosis induced by lack of sleep. Yet I too do not take medication or go to psychiatrists because I have always valued independence from institutions, at least psychiatric ones. I refuse to submit my agency to the will of another individual. It has been nearly 8 years since I was hospitalized and since I was prescribed seroquel. I graduated from school without the help of psychiatry and am always finding new ways to manage my thoughts and emotions. This is typically accomplished through a combination of self-acceptance and self-control. When one fails out, I got the other to lean on.   Right now I am trying to help my mom develop mechanisms for herself so that she doesn't have to rely on psychiatric medication to help her cope. She has a bi-polar and schizophrenic diagnosis and is currently hospitalized because of an experiment we tried to get her off her medication. It is scary how she sometimes fears that I am turning on her because she is so ill and will refuse to take my calls. It is particularly scary because she is a stubborn woman who won't listen to others once she's made up her mind. Luckily she loves me and so far has let me reassure her that I haven't turned on her. All I want for her is to thrive and besides my sister, I am all she has, but she has already strained her relationship with my sister who is always busy with work and school and it just leaves me. I don't know what I can do if she decides to cut me out of her life. She might be placed into a home or something if my sister refuses to carry some of the load and my mother refuses to let me help her.  I guess that's not the worse thing that can happen. I just feel bad that I could get rejected by my mom because of her illness and the quick conclusions she comes to in her paranoid states. It is freakin' ironic because I felt like I was being a bad son while going to school, leaving her to her own devices while she becomes more and more fatigued and overwhelmed by her psychiatrists and therapists. When I finally decide to start being a good son and try to help her, she gets even more ill and begins to fear me. The only thing I can do I guess is to be patient with her and reassure her that I respect her agency and her choices when she gives me the chance. Anyways, thanks to whoever read this far. I just needed to off load this. Cheers.

I think you should have done a bit more research into the effectiveness of these medications. Stimulates for ADHD are waaaaaay more effective than placebo, end of discussion. ADHD is the most easily treated mental health condition out there. Anti-depressants do much better than placebos when treating severe depression, and in combination with talk therapy out compete placebo for moderate depression. For mild depression, yes they do seem all but useless. I feel pretty similarly about psychiatry. When I was little I got diagnosed with ADHD and they give me aderall to 'treat' it for several months. Before that I had been put on multiple different drugs for it and none of them worked. They all either had no effect at all or they just made me sleepy. Finally when my mom found out that aderall is just meth in a pill form she took me off it cold turkey and said she was done with giving me pills. Later that day I went through a severe withdrawal but still I feel like I got lucky. My mom was pretty abusive but at least she got that right and I narrowly escaped the worst medication induced fates of many of my friends who became suicidal or permanently overweight due to a slowed metabolism from long term use of perscription drugs. Also I think a big factor contributed to over diagnosing human emotions as disorders is that for the parents get to enjoy the illusion of control over their child's abnormalness and emotional dilemmas by having a label to put on it and a majic pill that is supposed to fix everything instead of just accepting that they have no control and can't shield their children from going through the the negative mood swings that every teenager has to go through. They can't accept that it is normal and part of growing up. That might also be tied to larger societal expectations that everyone behave in a similar cookie cutter manner and that if your child doesn't fit that mold then they don't just have a different temperament. They have a 'disorder.' ADD and ADHD can serve as good examples of that. I personally don't think ADD kids are disabled so much as they just learn differently and are wired to perform certain types of tasks better than others and so they naturally gravitate towards those tasks. Yet another layer to this I have wondered about is whether or not some emotional disorders should be seen as diseases in their own right or if they should be seen as symptoms of deeper problems with the environment. For example, what if depression is not always a disease but a natural reaction to shitty circumstances that anyone would get depressed by if they were in the same situation? If we don't take that possibility into account then treating someone with a shitty life induced depression as mentally ill will not actually fix the problem and may even make them feel worse.

Huh. I was prescribed Seroquel for anxiety as well. It made my anxiety levels go through the roof. I told my doctor so he upped the dosage and told me to just keep taking it. I eventually ended up with anxiety so bad that i spent a weekend huddled up in the dark, unable to go outside or even turn the lights on, convincing myself that suicide was the only way to escape from it.  There was a little voice in the back of my mind telling me 'it's just the medication doing this. Just ride it out and you will be fine.' So, i did. I stopped taking the medication immediately and spent the next couple of weeks feeling pretty fucked, but still better than was i was feeling prior.  I remember when i went to see the doctor, in the waiting room, on the inter-television network that just shows doctor related commercials, there were constant commercials stating things like 1 in 3 people has a mental disorder and encouraging people to see their doctor for anything. When i reflected on what seeing my doctor and appointed therapist was like, i realised that they didn't really give a fuck. The doctor just wanted to write a prescription and tell me to see him in 2 weeks. Just in and out of his office asap with him doing as little work as possible. My therapist just wanted to listen to me talk, but he didn't really provide any insight or say anything to help me overcome my problems. He would occasionally spout a couple of technical terms, like 'cognitive dissonance' (which i remember rolling my eyes at every time. It felt like a buzz word of 2016), almost out of context some times, to try and convince me of his education. But mostly it was just, 'Keep talking about anything. Come back next week. Don't forget to pay at the counter on the way out' (not literally, but that was what the whole experience felt like).  My whole experience with 'Mental health services' felt like it was just a revolving door system designed to get a high volume of patients in and out, with little effort, to maximise profits and pedal drugs. They didn't even warn me of the potential negative effects of the shit they were pushing on me and payed no attention to my concerns that it was making me feel worse.

I went undiagnosed with ADHD until I was in 26.   By the time I reached that age my self esteem was terrible, because that's what happens when you have executive function problems and you don't know it. I didn't understand why I couldn't just *do* things like other people could. (If you're reading this and don't know what executive function is, please look it up. It's not something that's discussed enough.)   I was misdiagnosed with depression when I was 13, and that diagnosis stuck well into my adulthood. It got to the point where I was suicidal and turned to my doctors for help. I was diagnosed with ADHD. It was not a quick process. I had to take many tests, and go through hours of counseling. Finally my doctor agreed to medicate me (along with consistent counseling). Ritalin changed my life. My 'depression' almost immediately went away. I had a working memory. Tasks with multiple steps didn't overwhelm me. Tasks didn't have to be overly stimulating in order for me to do them. I enjoyed things again. I could get lost in a book, or zone out into a lame TV show.   And there are days when I go without taking my meds, and I'm just fine. Spacier, yeah. A little melancholy. I mostly feel like I felt before I started taking the meds. But it's not the same as coming down from 'high grade crystal meth.' Not even remotely. I know you're talking about your own experiences, but that's a dangerous misinformed statement that stigmatizes ADHD meds.  I have been in counseling from the time I was 5 years old. I have textbook ADHD (although I am a cis woman, so there's another layer to it). I sincerely believe that the stigma surrounding 'over diagnosing' is what caused me to go without a diagnosis. Going without a diagnosis ruined my acedemic career.   I'd suggest you check out the channel 'How To ADHD.' Even assuming you don't have ADHD, she does a great job of breaking down some of the misconceptions about it.  I understand that this video is older. I'd be curious what your thoughts would be now. I think there's a very fine line between skepticism of 'big pharma' and out and out stigmatizing psychiatric medication.

In addition to depression, I also have Meniere's disease (Thank autocorrect for the diacritics) - an inner ear condition that causes dizziness.  The similarities are obvious - sometimes the world spins because my inner ear is going on a bender, and sometimes I get all mopey and sullen because my brain is going on a bender.  Like depression, Meniere's is not a new disease, but it's also not terribly well understood in etiology and the treatments are a bit flaky (except they can cure Meniere's - too bad the cure leaves you deaf).  They both harm my quality of life and I'd gladly be rid of both of them, so I see no reason to approach them differently.

Left, right... Seems to me, its all just a work in progress to eventually center the collective mind..  Emotional (Extreme left) vs Logic (extreme right)...  Balance is everything, which is why 'true wisdom is knowing you know nothing.' (Socrates).       Each of these topics are just like objects in a room, our problem comes in when we perceive the object and interpret it and its ramifications through an extreme (Emotions or Logic). A lot of people dont know how antidepressants work, or why they have 'suicidal attitudes or thoughts' as a side effect. The brain works in a very sophisticated, yet simple way for the most part: receive information, translate information, react to information. This information forms pathways in our brain, and the more popular pathways get 'bigger' in a sense. The brain also learns to respond to certain types of information with different chemical outputs i.e. serotonin, dopamine, etc. An 'addiction' is just a really strong dopamine pathway, and 'depression' is a really strong pathway that tells the brain to react in a negative way. Certain chemicals are released when something bad happens to give us these 'emotions', and if the brain develops strong pathways to that reaction, you become depressed.  This is where antidepressants come in. Antidepressants work by counteracting the chemical balance your brain releases to cause depression, but everyone's brain is different. One type of antidepressants will work for some people and have the opposite effect on others.   That's why suicidal thoughts is a side effect, because if it's wrong for your brain it can imbalance those chemicals.

My entire family has chronic anxiety and depression issues, among others, and I have a lot of high needs foster siblings, so I've seen every side of this argument play out in real life. My brother threw insane, off the wall tantrums until he was almost 3, and doctors wanted to prescribe antidepressants. My mom refused, which was undoubtedly the right choice for him. His anxiety induced tantrums came from sensory sensitivity and an inability to communicate, and they started to dissipate on their own once learned how to talk. On the other hand, my one adopted sibling has been on ritalin since they were 3, which is undoubtedly the right choice for them. When trying to talk to them, you could actually see them trying their fucking hardest to focus on you and engage with you, and be unable to. It was really sad to have a kid who wanted so badly to focus and engage and just couldn't. Ritalin helped immensely. You can also compare me to my older sister. She tried all sorts of psychiatric drugs to manage her depression and mood swings, but what she really needed was help working through a sexual assault experience. The drugs didn't really help, the sexual assault centre did. Myself on the other hand... I have chronic anxiety that ranges anywhere from being mildly uncomfortable to being absolutely crippling. When I get on the right mix of meds, the symptoms completely disappear. I've had this my whole life, there's no one incident I can go back to to work through to make it go away. I wish I had found psychiatric medication so much earlier. Like, back when I was 12 earlier. My life would have been very different. The key to diagnosing and deciding on treatment needs to be: what's causing it, and how detrimental is it to your ability to live your every day life? How detrimental it is will determine whether or not it really is a medical condition and not just emotion/personality, and the cause will help point you to the correct treatment. Thankfully, more and more psychological treatment regimens are following that model, rather than jumping straight to medication.
Do your parents feel like all that money on psychiatry was wasted? You know... because of how you turned out...

I find this interesting because your experience has basically been the exact opposite of mine:   (under the cut for depression, suicidal ideation + attempt, flight arrest, general mental illness, and length)   I suffered from severe undiagnosed depression that I say started at age 10 because that's a convenient number (and sixth grade is when I tried to run away from home, ostensibly so that I wouldn't have to do homework, which is what the adults around me heard, but really because I was, even then, utterly fucking exhausted and convinced that my inability to summon the sustained energy to do things I hated on not enough sleep was somehow a moral failing and I was therefore a terrible person. It's just a good thing I didn't know how to conceptualize suicide at that age, because absolutely nobody did anything or even seemed to notice much. Anyway). It's very likely it's just always been there, though, that my brain hasn't worked right at all, ever, and even if I'd had the ideal Utopian upbringing I would still be tired all the time and think I was a horrible person for existing. I attempted suicide when I was 16, and it still took me two and a half more years, and going to college across the country, to realize that maybe I wasn't just amazingly shitty at dealing with normal things that everyone goes through.  The thing is, though, that I did get tested for depression. Multiple times. I even saw a therapist for a while, though I don't really remember much of it. But because I had functionally never been not depressed, I scored very low on the 'do you feel more X than normal?' questions, so clearly, I must not have depression. (Side note: when I take the MHQ-9 out of the blue, I usually score around 11-13. When I actually keep a running tally of the number of days I feel tired and shitty, I score around 25. The test is out of thirty. It is a badly designed test.) If literally anyone had been quicker to medicate me, I could have been saving literally YEARS of being told, by my own brain, that this was just the cover charge for living and I had better get used to it, and in fact that everyone else was obviously used to it already so I was just being a whiny little snowflake who needed to suck it up because it wasn't like I was anything special. I used to wish I had depression so that I would be 'allowed' to have the symptoms of depression, instead of what was clearly happening, which was that I was very bad at being a person. When I was in elementary school I used to fantasize about committing a crime so that I would get to go to jail and then I wouldn't have to do anything but lie there and stare at the ceiling all day. (I had a rather shaky concept of jail, but I was like eight, and I'm white.)  I don't know how to fix this in a way that doesn't result in more of your problem. I really don't. I don't remember much of high school, because I was so tired - usually just the worst moments - and even if I did, there's a 0% chance I would have the objectivity to see what other people saw when they looked at me, be able to match that to what was actually happening, and generalize to find signs of that in other people. I don't know how to design a written questionnaire such that a scared child who hates themselves, wants to die, and is desperately ashamed of it will accurately answer (at least, not in a way that doesn't involve lying to them). I don't know. I know that probably 95% of my attitude and outlook on life is the drugs I'm taking, and that becomes horrifyingly apparently when I go off them. I know that if you gave a neurotypical person my particular medical cocktail, they'd probably be just as miserable on them as I am off them. I don't disagree with you as such, I just... thought I should share. Maybe it will help someone else, I dunno.
