I don't really agree with much in this video (which is a surprise because I've loved every other video you have as I've caught up with your channel), or with the idea of there being a value-judgement in calling something a disease. I do agree that they aren't *diseases* per se, but rather syndromes, or clusters of symptoms. However, there's only a value-judgement in calling a mental illness an illness because there's a stigma to chronic illness, and we can attack that stigma at the core rather than refuse to call illnesses what they are.  I think treating mental illness as illness, no different than physical ailments, should help to reduce stigma. The mind and body are one, the separation is an illusion. My anxiety causes migraines and IBS flare ups, my depression causes fatigue and jaw-clenching. The mind and body are one, all the systems in the body affect each other. Thoughts and feelings are physical things, feelings hormonal changes and thoughts the firing of neurons and various neurotransmitters.   All that said, the psychiatric industry is currently just a few steps north of evil. We need integration with the rest of the medical field, universal healthcare, more personalized medicine, more coordination with doctors for non-mental ailments that may affect mental health and vice versa, and much much much less financial incentive. And I'd like ability to repeal a diagnosis if you get a second opinion. That absolute power that current psychs have, to decide whether or not a client is 'insane', is frightening. Also, please, fewer parents in psych! Easy for abusers to manipulate a conversation, harder for kids to open up about abuse.

The drugs are only slightly more effective than placebo because it often takes multiple drugs to find the right one. If you give 100 depressed people a drug, it's the perfect fit for 20 of them. The rest, in the real world, would get shuffled along to the next pill until they found the right one. In a study, the result gets averaged, and the drug looks ineffective. But the real issue is that the skill set of a psychiatrist lies precisely in the activity the studies cannot replicate: finding the right pill.

This is an excellent video and touches on a number of important critiques of psychiatry which are always worth analysis. I say that as a marginal YouTuber and a crusty old shrink who has dabbled in philosophy of psychiatry. At the heart of psychiatry, as you rightly point out, there is an inescapable tension between facts and values. DSM disorders don't cross the threshold into disorder unless they cause clinically significant functional impairment or distress. What constitutes distress or impaired function is sometimes really obvious, and the vast majority of us would agree; but many, many cases lie on different sorts of boundaries where, ultimately, a judgement call has to be made. Ideally, this is part of an ongoing negotiation between doctor and patient, to the degree possible. Would absolutely love to discuss some time if you were so amenable.

I'm surprised to see a video from contra that is so poorly researched.   Manic depression isn't just mood swings that goes away in minutes. The manic and depressed state may last weeks or months before switching. And it has to cause significant debilitation in the person's life, like he watches an episode of kitchen nightmare and then actually goes to the bank for a loan to open up a restaurant.  The reason anti-depressant causes more suicide isn't necessarily the anti depressant itself. The risk of suicide is heightened whenever someone with depression begins to improve.  When that person has enough motivation to get out of bed but still hopeless enough to want to kill themselves, you have the perfect ingredients to act on a suicidal ideation.
If it doesn't affect your ability to function in your daily activities, then it's not a mental condition.  Simple as that.

Truth is, we don't know much about people's moods or where they come from. Religion, meditation, and various coping strategies of all sorts are at least as useful as the meds the witch doctors are selling. The problem, of course, is that if you're really bad off, and you can't function, you can't use any sort of coping strategies effectively. Short term use of psychoactive meds can be useful for people who are in crisis - the research supports this. But long-term use hasn't been shown to be more than marginally useful, and the side effects are often significant.  I had a friend who suffered from 'social anxiety.' She had a job, she was good at it, she wrote bad novels (I read them and lied) and was generally capable of coping with life. She was 'flaky,' but I liked her for all that, I'm a little odd myself. But she was certain that her life could be better if she started getting psychiatric help. The doctor put her on various drugs, which gave her acne, put an unhealthy amount of weight on her with alarming speed, caused cramping and insomnia. But worse, she stopped writing. She wasn't a gifted writer, but it had always been meaningful to her. She said just couldn't focus on it under the influence of the drugs.  She mentioned the side effects to her psychiatrist, who put her on other drugs. With similar results. She started to blame herself, felt that she wasn't 'trying hard enough' in therapy, a ridiculous conclusion that wasn't helped when her psychiatrist told her she was being 'resistant.'  Then her insurance ran out. She couldn't afford the meds, so she suddenly discovered what happens when you cold turkey off this stuff. It was spectacularly bad for her. I spent a month basically keeping her away from sharp objects and street dealers, and helping her cope with the sickness.   She never got over the experience. Now, she's convinced she's a failure, her anxiety is worse than ever since she thinks she can't be helped, and she didn't leave her apartment for a year. She's never been able to go back to work, and she drove everyone away who tried to stick with her. Including me.  Eventually, her utilities were shut off. We had a blizzard, so I went over to check on her despite her telling me to stay away. She didn't have a phone anymore, so I had to go over, clear the snow away from the door, and knock. I heard her moving around, crying, so I opened the door. Yeah, I broke in. So sue me. I thought she was hurt. Stupid of me, I know, but this was before we all had phones in our pockets.  The apartment was freezing. No heat, no power, no water. She wouldn't even speak to me, she just went fetal on the couch and cried. I called the ambulance, and stayed until they arrived.   The State Hospital was a snake pit, and she came out just as bad once the Medicare ran out. She's gotten somewhat better, she pays the bills from her disability check, and she has recently gotten to the point that she can come to the door when the grocery delivery comes.  Bravo, psychiatry.

Yeah... there's a reason I've got a stronger interest in psychology than psychiatry.  Meds help some people, sure, but they're not for everyone. They weren't for me.   That said, there's discoveries neurologists have made about the brain in the last decade or so that are changing a lot of how we treat mental illness. Heck, for something truly random, there's inpatient facilities out there now with therapy goats. That's right. Therapy. Goats. Japan's also doing some pretty edgy stuff with discovering certain molecules they've extracted from Japanese cypress trees that help the brain battle depression and boost the immune system, and the effects of which are a lot more subtle.   Also the suicide risk in antidepressants Are NOT because they increase how suicidal you feel. Antidepressants increase suicide risk because depression fatigues you and makes you less able to carry out plans. The fatigue tends to fade before mood improves, so in that early stage of treatment you now have the energy to carry out a plan to harm yourself, but haven't yet lost the willingness to do so.

There's a good Ted talk on how we treat Schizophrenia and the way that we see it as a malicious thing crazy people have. The person giving the talk had received a high levelled degree in psychiatric study and they suggested it was probably thanks to their schizophrenia giving her half the answers. Throughout the talk she talks about how she was able to learn to live with unmedicated schizophrenia as she realised that the voices were in response to her brain rationalising emotions, much like how the brain will fill in the blank in optical illusions, text or memories if there are pieces of the puzzle missing. So when her anxiety, which was due to events in her childhood, made her feel heightened stress for no real reason one of her voices would start to speak saying things like 'everyone hates you', 'he's looking at you funny' or  'don't leave the house' which sounds like the thoughts of a malicious entity when in fact it was the brain experiencing emotions out of seemingly nowhere and rationalising the emotions with personalities and voices. She also recognised that whilst the voices would be aggressive it did seem that underneath it the phrases could be interpreted as the brain seeking what it thought was best for them. The talk is by Eleanor Longden and I've kind of posted my interpretation of what she said, I advise you, dear reader, to actually watch the talk rather than take my interpretation of someone else's dealing with mental health. I've mostly taken her points about personal experience and pushed them to what I believe is their logical conclusion.

I think one of the hardest things to consider in psychiatry is how imperceivable everything is. When you're dealing with say, electricity, you can look at what you're doing directly, see how Wire A attaches to Item B, and and what's causing problems and whatnot. Treating disease is like treating an extremely complex machine. You can know what's making you ill (like viruses and bacteria) but not be able to interact with it, or at least not without severely damaging what's around it. Either of those things are easier than psychiatry though. Unlike pneumonia or influenza, most of your symptoms aren't outwardly seen, and the things making you ill can't be put under a microscope and observed. Using the electrical analogy, making a mentally ill person healthy can be like trying to rewire your basement without the benefit of a flashlight.

Calling something a disease is not placing value on it. If that were true, you couldn't into medicine, ever. Medicine would not be a thing.   'Oh, bacteria are eating your leg? Well, we can't really put value on that...I mean, it IS statistically abnormal, but can we decide if it's bad for you? Surely not!'  I'm not a doctor, but 'disease' probably has some kind of definition, maybe even something talking about the well-being of the patient, danger or detriment to others etc.  Yes, sometimes it's not simple to determine how bad or not bad some condition is, but let's not throw out the concept of a disease (even a mental one) completely! Before anyone reads this understand that I went through the Australian medical system which -from what I can gather- is less trigger happy with prescriptions. Prescriptions cost less, and my psychiatrist has often joked to me about attempts by pharma companies to market to Australian Psychs. The way they market isn't as direct so as a general rule doctors are less susceptible to marketing. That being said there's still the issue of the evidence doctors use being biased. I was diagnosed with ADD/ADHD at 20 yrs old, I've taken Ritalin (under a different brand and formulation though) for four years. The reason I mention that is that Adderall is illegal in Australia. Adderall is made up of mixed amphetamines, and while Ritalin is very similar, it doesn't have the same addiction/dependence factor. Adderall contains dextroamphetamine which has the same effect as Meth, albeit without the same mechanism of action which can cause serious issues with dopamine that meth has. As for my own relatively positive introduction to psychiatry: Personally I can point to a period of my life where I suffered suicidal depression (at 17 yrs old) and was brought out by an anti-depressant. Mind you it wasn't an SSRI like Zoloft, it was a tetracyclic anti-depressant that worked a lot faster and didn't have the same level of side-effects. As for anti-psychotics, I've discussed this at great length with my psychiatrist. The conclusion he's come to is that when doctors are presented with a young patient who's suicidal, sedation may be the only tool at their disposal. A doctor will always see more benefit in prescribing when there's a chance of suicide, and I find that hard to fault. The other point my psych made was that like any other field of science medicine is dynamic: there's always an optimism that better treatments will present themselves.

I mean there's a lot of things that are really disorders that need to be treated, cancer is as natural as depression if you think about it. How much as our bodies work they just sometimes don't there's a lot of complex things happening in them. There's different levels of every disorder in some it influences a lot of more of their life than others.  For me therapy has done just so much, but only when I found a good therapist.  I've had a bad therapist and a therapist who just wasn't right for me, I think it's the same as any doctor really. When I was younger I was swinging between hyperactivity and staring out a window unable to hear a thing, I'd be playful and nice or I'd throw temper tantrums and break things out of anger, I lost things, I was bullied relentless, etc. Really I was the poster child for adhd. But when my parents took me to a psych to get diagnosis she said I had bipolar disorder. I did have a lot of issues with moods. But the truth was I had awful horrible extreme adhd. I didn't get a diagnosis until I was 17 it might have been fine if I wasn't such a serious case tbh. Adhd can cause anxiety and depression in ppl and boy did it ever. The first therapist I saw to get on antidepressants was just....  hm. Namby pamby is what my mom called her. She was just too nice to help me really. My current therapist is the best. She forces me to open up and helps me look at things I didn't see. The force thing sounds bad but I really need, for most of my life I not only would refuse to ask for help but I'd refuse to say the word b/c I wanted to be so independent. The medications I'm on really do help, they do a lot for me, it might just be a placebo effect but if it works it works no need for that to be a bad thing.  The reason I think therapy works so well for me is that I know I have problems and I reflect on my issues a lot. I know whats wrong with me 85% of the time but I just don't know what to do to fix it. My doctor helps me would with that and not just things about my mental illnesses but with my relationships and school and just a lot of things I was struggling with before. Therapy really only works for people who admit they have problems and are willing to do the work to fix those issues. Medicine works for chemical imbalances. I do think that some doctors push medicine too much (my current psych wants to give me like three new meds every time I see her, you just have to know when to say no) but it's hard too know what works. There is no cure all for everyone there's different  things that work for each person really. It's about finding what does. There is a lot of issues in psychiatry though it's not all help and rainbows. it's affordable to people who aren't middle class or above, which often people with disabilities have issues keeping a job because of their issues and if they have no money to fix those professionally they're just on their own, it's a bad cycle. A lot of doctors are actually pretty prejudiced against certain disorders, a lot of people with mood disorders (based on ppl I know and how the doctors I've seen have reacted when I've talked about people I know with mood disorders) have said that they felt the doctor was really negative about their disorder and said things that really just made the person feel worse. A lot of people who are actively suicidal don't want to tell their therapist because they're worried about being involuntarily committed. If a person can't tell their doctor about this disease that's potentially deadly they can't get help and that's a huge problem. Really mental hospitals in themselves are pretty shitty in so many cases. 1 person out of the 5 I know who've been committed said it helped, the rest honestly all have trauma connected to their stay. Mental hospitals are such a big issues that really isn't talked about enough.  There's positives and negatives but I think it's a huge mistake to just disregard psychiatry. It does save lives. But there are bad things about it too. There's horror stories in any medical field in all honestly. I could definitely tell some about my pcos. Doesn't mean medical fields should be treated like mistakes. It's a big issues and I hope people watching this video aren't scared away from help they may need to get.

I feel compelled to give you my life story???? So here goes.  I knew something was wrong with me in elementary, and I got a childhood diagnosis of ADD (now ADHD by proxy) not because I was hyper (although i did have a horrible personality) but because I physically could not do my homework no matter how hard I tried. My parents tried every non-medication technique they could think of to improve my grades but mom ended up just doing all the hard parts for me. I got put into a special grading regimen that allowed me to do more testing and less work, to prove efficiently that I was actually learning without having to struggle through mountains of late assignments, and in some cases to be able to study subjects alone with a textbook and worksheet. That was the entire reason I graduated high school. Somewhere along the way I started taking Concerta (after a mishap with Ritalin) and it felt like angels serenading me from the heavens.  My problem wasn't just homework-- I was barely able to do anything with personal hygiene, I barely ate, I barely exercised, and I couldn't even focus on video games. I was already writing fiction and drawing comics by puberty, but I could barely do a thing with them and completed almost no real finished pieces. I had a lot of ambitions-- I wanted to be a stand-up comedian, a marine biologist, a voice actor, an astronaut, an archaeologist, etc. Or at east run a kickass lemonade stand and do art commissions as a side job while flipping burgers for the corporate overlords. I was actually able to score an art commission in grade school but I wasn't able to follow through. I repeated basic mathematics over and over, I was too shy to get my foot in the entertainment industry door, too fat for even the military (I thought my mental health would be improved by strict schedules, and I needed the money), and too late into the recession for even mcdonalds. I ended up not going to college, so I could recuperate in the years following highschool, but I just ended up homeless when i had to move out of my mom's place due to stress.  I've been suicidal since age nine. I've always hated myself. I briefly stopping taking concerta to apply for the military, but without it, it was so hard to get back on that I became an adult in the meanwhile. I used to say it was like 'looking for your glasses' i.e. you need the thing to get the thing. I ended up reapplying for it but by then I had switched doctors and concerta had been bumped up to a schedual II drug-- they literally gave me a form with opium crossed out and concerta written in-- because of children who had been *misdiagnosed* selling their extra pills for skateboard money, to neurotypical college students who used concerta to pass difficult classes. Anyway my doctor thought I was a big liar so she took me off the pills and fucked me over. at 26 years old I've been medicated for less than three. There is *no alternative to concerta.* No off-brand, no substitute, not even in canada. I got put on buproprion, but as that was a antidepressant it did nothing but make me happy-depressed. Which was just... bittersweet.  Finally I figured out I was also trans and had bipolar thanks to the internet and free healthcare. I went on T and stopped being a demon child. Still can't brush my damn teeth. Still fat. Still not practicing art. Still homeless. Still jobless. I'm now on welfare, and still don't have my damned concerta. Still haven't completed Skyrim. Or Minecraft. Or Mario 64. Or Pokemon Blue. I've always wanted to be a youtuber actually, and I probably could, but..... I literally can't. And I still hate myself.  My current diagnoses are Clinical Depression, Generalized Anxiety, ADHD Mixed Type, Bipolar III, and also maybe BPD? That ended up on a report somewhere and I never asked about it. Currently my only medication is testosterone, and..... it's awesome, but I'm still super disabled. At this point I ID as crazy/insane, I just can't deal with anything sometimes... most of the time. Especially right now. I don't know if I have any sort of point, except that i think even if there was a perfect medication, which concerta isn't, it would probably be treated like opium and denied to the people who need it the most and used to drug misbehaving children and black market sold to struggling academists. Maybe my account of things helped someone somehow. I hope so. Bye. I love your videos.

What you described has been a hot topic in the psychiatric community and was disputed over intensly in the 50s 60s and 70s as the so called Anti-psychiatry. Back then psychiatric treatment often ment locking up patients for long periods which in combination with a lack of knowledge by family and friends led to high levels of stigmatisation. These disputes  promoted denial and in the end also changes in treatment and adding to the psychological and biological aspects of psychiatry a social one. If you want to learn more about this have a look at the work of Neel Burton.

I realize I'm a year late to the party but I just found this channel so whatever.  For the past two years I've been working as a Marriage & Family Therapist, so I provide talk therapy to people struggling with basically the whole gamut of diagnoses in DSM.  I talk to people for an hour at a time, getting deep into the weeds not just with their 'symptoms' but with their whole background, taking into account race, culture, socioeconomic status, gender, LGBT+ status, and many other things besides.  Even then, I was trained to be extremely cautious about offering any diagnosis, and extremely skeptical of the 'medical model' that treats clients as sick people with some kind of disease we can diagnose and 'cure.'  The only reasons to do diagnose, according to the postmodern ivory tower rhetoric of graduate school, are if the client agrees and finds the label helpful or if a label is needed to unlock access to additional services (i.e. to bill the client's insurance).  To do otherwise is considered to be 'pathologizing' the client, which is understood to do more harm than good.    I say all this to put some context to the professional environment of the vast majority of psychiatrists: like me, they are trying to understand what the client is struggling with and how to help them.  Unlike an MFT like me they don't get hours at a time to go into all those weeds.  Statistically what they get instead they get 4-20 minutes at a time, usually once a month or so.  Thus even a (very) hypothetical well-meaning, ethical, and intelligent psychiatrist is to a disturbing degree taking a wild shot in the dark about the neurochemical origins of a problem while totally ignoring all other factors (race, gender, culture, SES, etc etc etc).  This leads to rampant misdiagnosis, enrolling people in the roulette wheel of Powerful Psychotropic Drugs who should never be there and dealing out ineffective or actively harmful medication to others.    All of which is, I guess, to say that it's an extremely flawed system at best, so beware ye who enter.  The right medication in the right brain at the right time CAN genuinely be like a magic bullet that makes everything a thousand percent better, but the odds are honestly probably much higher that the effects will be slight, nonexistent, or actually harmful.  The state of informed consent around all this is absolutely dreadful.  I would recommend that everyone advocate very strongly for themselves and their own self care and mental health, because psychiatric professionals need to be held accountable for genuine positive result.  If someone doesn't know how to advocate for themselves or does not feel comfortable doing so, collaborating with another mental health professional (like an MFT) might be helpful to collaboratively develop a strategy for that sort of self-advocacy, or the therapist may be able and willing to advocate on the client's behalf.  tl;dr: Diagnosis is a total crapshoot, psychopharmacology is more of a total crapshoot than we might be comfortable admitting, and the professional practices of 'medical model' mental health treatment leave a lot to be desired.  Great video, as always.  Hope this added a least a little value to the discussion.

Late reply, to the video, and some great points were made.  Knowing what words to say can indeed guide the doctor to give you the diagnosis you are looking for. The major problem in getting an accurate diagnosis is that psychiatrists are not mind readers.  They can't X-ray your brain and tell you whats wrong.  The most common mistake is diagnosis come from confusing a mental disease from a personality disorder.  With conditions like schizophrenia, something has gone wrong.  There is an identifiable chemical imbalance that manifests systems, and there are medications to try and correct that imbalance.  With a personality disorder, everything is functioning correctly, but still yields bad results for the patient.  Personality disorders are tough because medication is very ineffective as a treatment.  Therapy is the best solution, but individuals with personality disorders are often resistant to go to therapy.  Do you have problems holding on to long term relationship with friends or family? Do you have intense outbursts of anger or depression that last only a few hours?  Crippling fear abandonment?  Substance abuse?  These are often the hallmarks of a borderline personality disorder, and it is often mistaken for other conditions such as bipolar.  Not to E-diagnose anyone, but the fact that you have had multiple diagnosis from different mental health professionals to me seems to indicate that there is indeed a mental health issue at play, but they are focusing on the wrong symptoms     Not to mention there was an aspect of yourself that you were more than likely hiding from others at the time, which probably led to a lot of social angst that others might interpret as a medical condition.  Many in the LGBTQ community who are in the closet are often diagnosed with some malady or another because the outward symptoms of anger, social withdrawal, and subsequent suicidal thoughts are all the doctor can see, and often lead to a misdiagnosis.

I worked as a behavioral technician at a for-profit hospital for about 2.5 years, and saw patients from 18 years old to 80. My dad is a practicing psychiatrist. And I can assure you that--based on what I've observed and what I've heard from my dad's 30 years experience--your dealings with psychiatry are probably the most typical kind of experience.    Most diagnoses are not really medical in nature--as you point out, they're value judgments. I have observed that these judgments are used as methods of control. The police routinely brought patients to the ER who were disorderly, perhaps had a falling out with a loved one or were already known to the authorities to be a 'problem.' From the ER, the overworked staff would see the problem and seek to extirpate him or (more often) her somewhere else--often our 48 bed hospital.   Of course, I saw sick people as well, but I would estimate that no more than 15% of the patient population was truly possessed of a medical condition--major depression, schizophrenia, psychosis, bipolar being the most powerfully debilitating and terrible to behold.  As one example of how extreme real illness can be, I met a man who thought the world was perpetually burning down. I've never felt such pity for another person in my whole life, and the tortured screams that projected from his quivering, huddled frame--all because the television was plugged in to the wall and would imminently engulf us both in flames--will follow me to the end of my days.   But most of the people I encountered were more or less normal. Plenty of drug addicts--heroine especially; domestic disputes; drunken mistakes; what was termed 'personality disorder,' ie this person is annoying and a pain in the ass... Nothing too special, except in so far as their very normality should have been so out of place!
In my experience, I would say that it was necessary, because of how you feel about it and yourself once you have gotten past it all.

The 'antidepressants are no better than placebo' study was seriously flawed because it does not reflect clinical practice. Basically, each patient tested only one antidepressant, but in clinical practice most patients will try multiple medications before finding the one that works. See: URL  The NIH's STAR*D study was a much larger study which actually reflects clinical practice. URL  Hopefully at some point our understanding of Major Depressive Disorder and neuroimaging will advance enough that patients can be given the right antidepressant the first time. Currently the most that clinicians have to go on is whether the patient has any other psychiatric diagnosis which can give a clue as to which antidepressant might work best. But it's by no means an exact science.  Do I think some people have been given psychiatric drugs when what they actually need is psychological counselling? Of course. But the problem is actually one of access to psychiatry, not too much psychiatry. Proper diagnosis takes time, and a psychiatrist's time is too expensive (currently even in single payer systems, like here in the UK where patients will often only manage to see a mental health nurse, not a psychiatrist).

I know I'm real late, but I'd like to add some quick input. I'm autistic and also diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder and major depressive disorder. These are very accurate diagnoses for me - however, I also show a multitude of traits of other psychiatric disorders that have negatively impacted my life, which get ignored. I had to jump through hoops to get the diagnoses I have now, and many of my friends did as well. Even if they're clearly mentally ill, they haven't been diagnosed or had to go to great lengths to get their diagnoses. Here's the interesting bit - I'm Canadian.  There's a significantly smaller profit motive, and suddenly we have very clearly mentally ill people being denied the care they need. Flip to the US, where there's a ton of money to be made, and people are being overdiagnosed and assigned a ton of meds.  All this to say that society is incredibly capitalist and ableist and will screw over mentally ill people if there's no profit, but make a business out of harmful practices if it can turn over a few bills. But I guess I'm really preaching to the choir.

My experience with therapists is that they went out of their way to make the point that emotions are not pathologies, and that therapy isn't about getting rid of behavior that deviates from the norm, almost the opposite, they want you to get better at accepting your own bizarre behavior.  If you have a problem you want fixed, like showing up to work late every day, they'll use their expertise to find ways to fix that, especially if you're stuck in some weird ironic delusional loop where you procrastinate in the morning because you're afraid of being late. But so far the therapists I've dealt with would have an attitude like 'yeah, I can help you show up on time, but another approach could be looking at jobs that aren't so asinine about punctuality.'  This seems to be standard expected industry practice, but I've heard enough horror stories to think that most therapists are daft and don't follow the research or currently accepted standards, and will sometimes even try to literally heal you with crystals or Reiki or something.

I feel compelled to comment, and I may or may not be a therapist for a day job... And  know that you made this video a long time ago.   The big problem with mental health treatment in general is that it's a buyer-beware market and there are a bunch of history reasons for it. Basically, there was Freud, and then there was the DSM. DSM is basically lists. U meet enough of the list requirements, u get the diagnosis. in the 50s, we figured out that psychiatric drugs made people with severe MH issues stable enough to go home; even pick up part time work in some cases. Capitalism took over, and all the asylums closed by the mid 80s to early 90s with the idea that community MH providers would be the ones handing out the drugs like the asylums were 30ish years earlier. Capitalism under clinton made that not happen and jails/prison took over much of MH work in general... a trend that has only gotten much, much worse to this day (I may or may not work in SUD, and i can tell you that Obamacare made things only mildly better for methadone clinics in my state and not necessarily for NOT methadone types of treatments (not everyone should be on medication replacement therapies, not everyone wants them, there are plenty of other therapies out there we can try, etc.).   So to your point and your life story, it's not surprising, especially since the DSM has grown more affinity for behavior rather than innate 'personality' disorder issues in recent decades. ADD is a real thing, but the list I talked about in the DSM has an innate bias when talking about children; who will always exhibit more behaviors congruent with the list than adults and there's an incredible amount of leeway for the person doing the diagnosing; where personal values most definitely play a part in therapists who are bad at their jobs. On top of that, there's a huge push to medicate problems because... well that's a whole other set of issues I kept typing and deleting when they got longer than 5 sentences....   Essentially, most mental health problems, according to these lists, NOT all-but most, can be briefly summed up as: are you able to work for 40 hours a week? no? here's a pill/tx (treatment) that might work for you. in my line of work, which may or may not be related to these kinds of things, I've found that trauma is often at the heart of most issues and medication only sort of helps.... usually what seems to be most effective is telling patients to read philosophy, find purpose and meaning in their lives, and take their ancestors and personal responsibilities more seriously. Often times, ive found that people are misdiagnosed damn near all the time, and it takes about a month of seeing someone once a week to figure out what best diagnosis would fit them and what tx would be most effective. full disclosure, most therapists in my observation as both someone in therapy and on the other side of the desk are pretty shit. I would never tell anyone to not go to therapy, but I would warn people that they are going to have to figure a lot of stuff out on their own, be generally aware and familiar with what OTHER diagnosis's their list of behaviors would also qualify for and ask their therapist why those weren't considered, and they shouldn't be afraid to shop around 2-8 times to find a therapist they click with... which can be pretty costly, sometimes looks like drug seeking, and insurance tends to not like it; unless your 'in-house' at an agency where having a different therapist week after week doesn't really matter.   in short, it's always easier to prescribe a pill than to see someone once a week for 180 days; letting them take up 60 mins of your time and another 15-60 mins in administrative stuffs you might not always get paid to do. Also, psychiatrists will ALWAYS prescribe you something if you present them with enough problems. It isn't a malicious or generally conspiratorial thing... it's just capitalism, the nature of the DSM, and the the human organic brain laughing at western concepts of mind/body dichotomy and the pressures of ultra capitalism where mh is stigmatized because our sole value as human beings is wage labor.

Ive been diagnosed with everything under the sun, and while I do consider my depression/anxiety debilitating and severe without maintaining a certain vitamin regimen, the thing that saved me was simply St Johns Wort and 5-htp combined with exercise and a healthy diet. I also take fish oil and multivitamins, but I know its mainly the 5-htp st johns wort combo that allows me to feel normal. Otherwise I tend to lose all ability to function and go days feeling like life is pointless and hopeless. I used to drink constantly 2 or so bottles of wine a night to cope, and I felt really out of control of my life, but i couldn't bring myself to care. The side effects during hangovers were mainly even more extreme versions of anxiety though, so I had to figure out a different way to medicate in spite of trying medication after medication starting at 15 years old. I've been diagnosed with OCD, depression, generalized anxiety, ADHD, and been on at least 6 different meds. None of the meds ever helped, in fact they seemed to make me feel even less rational and more hopeless. I still drink often, dont get me wrong, but it's a lot more manageable when you're not drinking because you don't care if you live or die anymore and I don't do it just to escape from the hell of being unable to feel happy. I also take naltrexone which stops the opioid reaction in the brain you get from alcohol, which I would totally recommend. You can still enjoy drinking and get drunk, but its easier to be rational about it. Theres no sense ending up in a hospital due to withdrawals some day down the road. Contrapoints, I would really recommend giving 5-htp and st johns wort a shot if youre still even slightly chronically depressed. I recommend it to anyone I hear is struggling with depression/anxiety because its just so shitty living like that when a simple herb can make such a difference. Youll feel the effects within 2-3 days, and you can get it at walmart, trader joes or online. I find it amazing that this herb has made such a difference for both myself and my brother, and we both felt awful and completely not ourselves on the cocktail of medications psychiatrists and doctors kept giving us. So, I grew up in an extremely religious working-class family that didn't believe mental illness was a thing even though damn nearly my entire paternal extended family suffers from addiction issues and/or some form of comorbid psychiatric disorder. I had my first bout of depression at 14 years old, and it took ten more years, wrecked credit, and multiple suicide attempts before I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder. I have a very classic presentation of the illness; it took the first person I saw all of fifteen minutes doing intake to be like 'yep you gots the manic depression, sucks to be you'. I've been taking medication for it off and on ever since.  The point I'm trying to make here is that even when you have the thing they say you do, these drugs *fucking suck* to have to take. The knowledge that people have been prescribed psych meds when they didn't need them honestly makes me cringe, because long-term use should only be a thing if you absolutely NEED long-term medication. It's like taking drugs for any other serious condition, the side effects can really fuck you up, sometimes permanently. I also know several people who were misdiagnosed with psychiatric illnesses, or had an underlying issue that could have been resolved through talk therapy rather than pills and their doctor just threw the pills at them and wondered why it didn't fix anything.   I feel like in a lot of ways we as a society haven't destigmatized mental illness or personal struggle so much as we've merely pathologized it, so the method that doesn't require a lot of bedside manner, effort, or personal investment on the physician's side has taken precedence.

The problem with modern psychiatry, (with the exception of a lot of cutting edge science focused on holistic healing methods) is that they are overly focused on symptomology and treating that, rather than providing cures. It's like if you had cancer and the doctor only prescribed pain medication without chemotherapy.  So, an illustration of curing a mental illness would be more like giving an unmotivated depressed person aderol and SSRIs to get them interacting with the world again AND treating the symptom of their debilitating sadness. This isn't a cure all for depression, but when psychiatrists start to focus on treating the patients needs and unfufilled desires in life then they can cure the root of mental illness, which is caused by needing to cope with the shittier parts of life, :(.  Things are changing for the better though, :)

Hey Contra, have you looked much into philosophy about this stuff?  The Foucauldian Ian Hacking's work for example is fascinating, talking about the socially constructed recursive linguistic/conceptual stuff behind diagnostic categories and other kinds of psychological knowledge. It's not quite antipsychiatry but there's some consonance I suppose.  URL  I'm a training therapist and Psych doc student interested in 'critical psychology' that uses philosophy and critical theory to take a look at psychology/psychiatry. Critical psych is cool, emphasizes more of the sociopolitical, looking at western individualism, neoliberalism, etc.  I've been appreciating your videos and thought 'uh oh' when I saw one on psychiatry, but I like your perspective here!

Psychiatry, as it currently stands, is based more on politics than it is on science.  In fact, it's probably been like that for decades.  Schizophrenia, for example, only has the current stigma attached to it (the one of violent, inhuman behavior) because of racist underpinning during the Civil Rights Movement, where black protesters were diagnosed as schizophrenic to discredit their beliefs and fear-monger about their actions.  Women have a harder time receiving treatment, even when it would be useful, because they are seen as inherently 'more moody' or what-have-you, and black children receive far 'harsher' diagnoses than white children, again, because of institutional racism and stigma.  And I think, so long as we continue to view psychiatry as a purely scientific field, thus controlled by purely scientific individuals who strive for objectivity out of the goodness of their hearts, instead of as a deeply flawed system that often harms the very people it claims to want to 'cure', mentally ill people will continue to be abused by the psychiatric system - which is something that happens very frequently.  Alarmingly frequently.  It has happened to me and many of my closest friends who are in a similar boat.  But it's hard for mentally ill people to be taken seriously about our own mistreatment.  We are, inherently, 'out of our minds'.  We are paranoid, we seek to victimize ourselves, we are hypersensitive, we are delusional.  So when we say 'My doctor is hurting me', that's just another sign that we need MORE doctors.  When I was put on Seroquel - an anti psychotic with horrible side effects - for my schizoaffective, I continuously begged to be taken off of it because it made me so miserable.  I was told, every time, that I just didn't realize I was sick and needed the meds, so that was a sign I definitely shouldn't be taken off the meds yet.  I was eventually taken off of it because I flunked two classes and gained about 80 pounds and nearly killed myself, but it was really only at that point did anyone believe me about it doing more harm than good.  And I guess I can't blame them, because I was psychotic at the time, and you don't trust psychotic people to know what's best for them.  Just kidding. I can blame them, and I do. Us psychos really hold a grudge!  This comment ended up way longer than intended.  I'm really passionate about this, if you can't tell!  This video was really fascinating to watch, and really brilliantly put, as all your videos are.

Medicine, including psychiatry, is an art, not a science.  There is medical science, but that is not what doctors practice.  They take the science that others pursue and try to apply it to real world situations where they can't use the scientific method effectively because the patient is always a data set with one member.  Psychiatrists, as you note, are further limited because they often are relying on the self-reports of patients who may not have a broad understanding of mental conditions to liken own experiences to.  The psychiatrists (and doctors generally) rarely survey they medical literature on drugs being prescribed, as if to try to independently verify their effectiveness.  (Which is why I am always skeptical of movements to make the FDA review of drugs less rigorous to get new drugs approved faster, although I get that people with serious illnesses can find it maddening that a drug they feel they need will be delayed for many years by government 'red tape,' so there are two sides to the issue).

I can't speak for the American psychiatry, but only for the German. Over here, psychiatry has become increasingly cautious determining a diagnosis when people are still children, teenager or young adults. A vital factor is always the experienced loss of quality of life that the patient experiences. In my experience, some psychiatrists are quick to ask patients if they want to try out medication, especially if they suffer from a loss of functionality in their daily life. However, they also always stress the importance of psychotherapy, which has proven to be more effective than medication especially in the long run (except for schizophrenia, which is something entirely different). Patients are always encouraged to connect with a psychotherapist even before they leave the clinic so they have someone to support them professionally as soon as they get back to their daily routines outside. Luckily, nobody needs to pay for therapy themselves here, which is a huge plus. Overall, I am wary of medication myself because it equals firing a cannon at a tiny bird flying in the sky - you can be lucky and it helps you fine, or it can be the start of a year long struggle to find the right medication, only that it turns out that every drug gives you unbearable side effects.  Psychotherapy should always come first, if possible.

Hey ContraPoints, great video!  Of course, as a future psychiatrist I have a couple of disagreements but overall I think your analysis is spot on.  ;-)  1.) It's true that the evidence shows SSRIs aren't all that effective in mild to moderate depression, but they do appear to work well for those with major depression and generalized anxiety disorder.  2.) Many of the younger/newer psychiatrists are choosing to medicate less and use psychotherapy (including alternative methods such as mindfulness practice) more often than the previous generation, so hopefully this pattern of over-medication fades out.  3.)  You said: 'The decision to treat a pattern of thoughts and emotions as a disease can never be a fully scientific one.'  I would argue that it can be scientific if a biological basis (e.g. altered brain structure, or some other underlying physiological process driving those thoughts) can be identified in the condition.  That said, that's probably the minority of patients.  P.S. I meant it when I said you'd be legit good at ASMR.  I'll love you forever and ever if you make an ASMR video!  Maybe just for your patrons?  <3

I was a mental health advocate for involuntary patients seeking release from mental health facilities, in Canada, for a summer.  It was an eye opening experience to the pharmaceutical world. In particular, I recall one client, brought into the facility because of drug induced psychosis.  She had been later diagnosed with severe ADHD after her drug induced psychosis symptoms were gone, likely because she still wanted to go back to work as an escort and her psychiatrist wanted to protect her. A big problem with psychiatry/psychology is that a very large portion of psychiatrists/psychologists are really, really, really, really bad. Like, the underlying science is completely sound and good, but the practitioners are often extremely dumb and wrong about many important things.  I think this is largely due to the fact that they misinterpret psychiatry as being similar to other forms of medicine, where treatments usually directly target the condition/symptoms in question and we more or less understand how they work. But in the case of psychiatry, psychiatric conditions are often very vaguely defined and are likely caused by a large variety of different things. Take 'Depression' for example. Chances are there isn't just one specific medical illness that causes 'Depression.' Depression is just a collection of symptoms that can likely be caused by a variety of different underlying conditions (that we unfortunately can't really examine since we can't cut open peoples' brains).   But a lot of psychiatrists don't understand everything I just mentioned above. They come up with their own stupid ideas based upon their personal experiences (like 'SSRI X is better for 'energy' than SSRI Y' - a literal thing I've heard). As an educated person who works in a field vaguely related to academia (a programmer for a web tool used by biologists, so I work with a bunch of geneticists and what have you), I genuinely think that I know more than a very large number of psychiatrists. This isn't so much because I'm smart or anything, but because a lot of psychiatrists do not continue to learn about the field (which obviously frequently changes) and also have pretty questionable abilities to think scientifically and understand scientific literature (which is a problem common among MDs as well). Ironically, the best psychiatrist I ever had was this young guy in the middle of his residency who I saw during college. He was the only one who seemed to understand the uncertain nature of the medications prescribed and the fact that psychiatry is largely a matter of just trial and error.  As a general rule, if you go to a psychiatry, get prescribed with Depression, and are then prescribed a newer, brand-name (non-generic) SSRI, you should change doctors. Many psychiatrists just believe the drug reps who come and tell them 'this SSRI is totally awesome and better than earlier ones' and then pass on that bad knowledge to their patients.  So I guess to sum up, as I said at the beginning the science of psychiatry is mostly good (or at least not any worse than any other medical science), but it has some serious problems with bad practitioners.

Have you read Mad in America or looked into the Mad Pride movement?  In my case I think of some of my mental illnesses as diseases (the intrusive suicidal ideation and self-harm images get... rough), some as the reaction any reasonable person would have to severe chronic pain and stuck with a significantly disabled body, while others (ADHD and ASD, specifically, and somewhat anxiety) are just my brain behaving in a different way from normal society and it adds valuable diversity and robustness to Humanity as a whole.  And honestly, this is why I'm in favor of self-diagnosis. Doctors are notoriously bad at telling whether someone is 'mad' or 'sane' (whatever those may be) even in a hospital setting, let alone figuring out exactly what's wrong (my ADHD was misdiagnosed as bipolar disorder), and don't even get me started on how many psychiatrists don't recognize ASD unless it's in a young, white, male patient.   If it's a handy matrix to understand how you interact with the world, whatever. Like everything it can be mishandled, and education helps guard against that, but I don't care enough about gatekeeping to really give a shit. *shrug*  Most of my friends figure out well before going to their doctor that they have anxiety or depression, and then they look online for coping habits and remedies as they wait for eons on the bureaucratic wheels of the healthcare field of finally get them in front of a doctor.  But we should also accept those who are mentally ill who reject the psychiatric industry wholesale, and pay particular attention to those who have been abused by it and are ringing the warning bells about forced medication (I had a friend with epilepsy who was 'not-technically-forced' to do ECT for her depression, otherwise she would've been taken from living independently in the community and forced into a group home 'for her own good').

Part of the problem is a phenomenon called 'scapegoat diagnosis.' Scapegoat diagnosis is something I myself have experience with, almost as the inverse to your experience, funnily enough. Scapegoat diagnosis is when you have a mental illness or other neurodiversity that's more complex or 'difficult' than your professional wants to deal with- such as bpd or schizophrenia spectrum disorder- so they diagnose you with something 'simpler' like anxiety or depression, ignoring your other symptoms for convenience's sake. This is especially damaging when you have both.  For a good few years, I was treated for generalized anxiety disorder by a Freudian charlatan who did far more harm than good, pathologising my grey-ace sexuality and my emerging gender identity as something to do with parental problems. When I finally saw a real professional it took over half a year for them to acknowledge that most of my symptoms- hallucinations, delusions, obsessions and compulsions, instability in relationships and attachments- were far outside of the GAD diagnosis. It's also been a horrendous struggle getting my parents to acknowledge each new diagnosis, due to their (largely valid) skepticism regarding the amount of diagnosis I have, and they don't even know about half of the things I've discussed with my psychiatrist+psychologist. So far, I've been diagnosed with PTSD, C-PTSD, moral injury (debated whether it's a type of PTSD or just a facet of standard PTSD), OCD, double depression and psychosis+personality disorder traits, and I've been advised to screen myself for autism, ADD and dyspraxia.  Psychiatry as a profession fucking sucks, to be blunt. Its founder was a pseudoscientist and it's only started seeing something resembling real scientific rigour in very recent years- and even much of that is still very questionable.   Giving a teenager a dangerous, hardcore bipolar drug (lithium carbonate) to treat dysthymia is a shit idea. But they did that anyway, after misdiagnosing me with cyclothymia. Luckily I ended up being taken off those pills after the nausea started.  My treatment began in New Zealand- a country with a notoriously shitty medical system, lagging decades behind in many areas, and where I was living at the time- and unfortunately was cut short after I returned to England. However, I should be starting again soon, and I'm very grateful. I've seen real improvements and I only wish I'd spoken up about my symptoms sooner. I just hope they don't try to put me through hell for my autism, god knows they handle that in a borderline eugenicist manner a lot of the time... In fact, the ignorance of doctors towards neurodiversity is the scariest thing for me. Autism should never be treated as something to be 'cured'. Doing so puts autistic people through hell and causes untold suffering through quackery like ABA. I need to be validated by the medical system though, in order to recieve the help I need in the educational system.

Skimming the comments, I must be lucky as all balls, because I've never had a doctor try to enforce some imaginary standard of normalcy on me (and I have two chronic conditions that necessitate a raft of specialists each)... they ask, 'What's the problem?' and if there's something that I don't want to fix, they don't press the issue. In particular, my psychologist helped me with a gaming addiction, but first he asked, you know, if you want to do this for a living, make a career of it, you can do that. I didn't, 'cuz I wanted to be an artist, so he helped me accomplish that. (Which meant giving up video-games cold turkey), but we both tried our level best to work out a solution without giving them up for the longest time, 'til I realized it was gonna be one or the other, so I made my decision and he helped me see it through). Course, the difference between a psychologist and a psychiatrist is that the former will help you fix your problems, while the latter can proscribe you something... when all you have is a hammer, the whole world looks like a nail. (Also, I live in Canada, so things are probably somewhat different up here).

My perspective? I barely scraped through high school. All my teachers said pretty much the same thing: Smart kid, doesn't do his homework. Disorganized, absent minded. But, I'd sit quietly in class with my nose in a library book, and wasn't one of those kids who was constantly bouncing off the walls. Wasn't until I bombed out of college (exact same thing happened; did well in class, didn't get assignments done) that I saw a psychologist (about an unrelated issue), and he got me what I really needed: ritalin (turns out, I had ADD, which is more typical in girls than boys, who usually have ADHD, so no one even suspected it cuz I wasn't bouncing off the walls). I'd spent years blaming myself for inadequacy... I was smart, I understood what was being taught in class, I just never seemed to test well.   Here's the thing: if you don't need ritalin, or antidepressants, or what have you, taking them is a very bad idea. The people who do need them? Cannot get by without. There is no substitute. It's not a matter of behavioural problems, or bad parenting. You can't discipline away a medical problem... well, not most of 'em, at least. If there's a real solution, I'd say that parents (and doctors) need to be properly informed, to know what to look for, and to pay attention to their children, actually listen to them, and make sure the treatment they get is working as it should. I think most parents just want a magic bullet pill that will fix everything and make all the problems go away, but human beings just aren't that straightforward... especially children.  I don't think people in general really understand mental problems... physical problems, yeah: it's understood that, as a diabetic, I can't just decide to get by without insulin. Mental issues? Everyone thinks it all comes down to mind over matter. If you're dumb, you need to smarten up... if you're prone to deviant behaviour, you need to straighten yourself out. If you're emotional, you just need to chill out. Like you can just change your mind like you change your clothes. There are things that can be done to  alter your behaviour and mindset, but the brain is not a computer that we can just reprogram when we don't like how it thinks.

Hi! I like a lot of your videos, but I think this was not one of your strongest videos. The reason for that is because I feel like this video fundamentally is about two different points. The first point you seemed to be talking about was the definition of 'disease,' and how social perceptions affect ideas of 'wellness.' The second point you were trying to make seemed to be about a perverse incentive that might exist among psychiatrists to over proscribe certain medications, for economic reasons. There is research into this issue of perverse incentives, and I think a fairly accessible point was made in a series by the Freakanomics podcast about the healthcare field (The last part of which, most focused on this issue of prescriptions, can be found here; URL  While I think I understand why you wanted to include those two points together, namely to say that some sort of perverse incentives or profit motive may impact the way people try to define 'disease' in society, I kinda think that somewhere in between the tentacles those points got lost.  Lastly, I think that part of it was that you put this whole video through the lens of your personal experience. As a fan I'm actually really happy to have some sort of insight into who you are because of it, but from the perspective of the points in the video, it was like a whole third element being put on top of those two other elements I talked about. It was a lot of stuff.  I think this video would have been better had it been a more compartmentalized video, similar to your Baltimore or White Nationalism videos, or even split it into multiple videos.  Thanks, and overall good work on your videos!

Hi, I'm a semester away from a bachelor's in Psychology (and maybe a year away from one in Neuroscience if I wanted it) so I just wanted to add some of what I've learned in school.  When we talk about mental disorders, they're usually only classified or described in the DSM if they're considered 'maladaptive'.  In essence, only if they're of a significant detriment to the person's life where they're either suffering because of it or are missing what most people would consider important human qualities (ie: a person with antisocial disorder isn't personally bothered by their brain, typically, but understands they're missing something we consider important)  With that in mind, I do agree that all your drugs and therapies were probably unnecessary.  At least with the way you phrased your story, it sounded like your parents saw you do something strange and asked a professional about it before asking you.  So your therapies may have never been *for* you, but for your parents.  That isn't to say no one had your well-being in mind, it's just that it's not very common for parents to let children take responsibility for what they're doing or what they want to be. (if that makes sense?  sometimes i no good words)  Anyway, it seems like (from my point of view) that your diagnoses were a little rushed (with OCD they usually do not diagnose without the compulsion to do the repetitive actions; you'd need an excuse like 'I will die if I don't spend hours in the bathroom' or whatever), especially because at least *I* was taught that people going into psychology should keep in mind that a diagnosis may harm the patient more than help.  In your case it was medicine you probably didn't need.  In other cases, people will think they're somehow sub-human because their brain isn't working in a 'correct' way.  I don't think I have to explain why that'd hurt some one with Depression or anxiety.  The other thing I wanted to contribute was that I agree with how we shouldn't medicate certain ways of behavior or thought.  As I said, we try not to do it unless it's maladaptive.  In the current DSM, there is no treatment suggestions for Gender Dysphoria (talking about why that's in there is a slippery slope already), and there's an arousal disorder described as happening when ONLY A WOMAN isn't interested in sex or has no sense of sexual attraction or whatever. In it's core, all these diagnoses and garbage are meant to help people get over things that may cause them discomfort or invisible pain or keep them from living a life without fear or whatever, but obviously there's still a lot of work to be done, and a lotta shitty people that shouldn't be contributing. Have you read William Davies' The Happiness Industry?  It touches on a number of these ideas and shares similar conclusions, though skepticism toward medicalizing others' inconvenient behavior is probably very old and with a robust literature that you have on the shelf behind you.   I am one of those whose life was saved by psychiatry, though in adulthood after making the terrible mistake of going to grad school for a Ph.D. in the humanities, where rates of depression and suicide are very high. In the span of about a year I went from planning my own suicide to completing my dissertation and getting the hell out of that lunatic profession. I didn't get any drugs, though, just cognitive behavioral therapy that communicated ways of thinking that continue to help me years later in my calmer, blander 30s.  My experience is of course anecdotal, but I found it useful and a very useful education to see a psychiatrist. It was a little like having a philosopher on retainer who was paid to be interested in my problems.  If I had gotten a crackpot, it probably would have killed me though.

It's an unpopular opinion but I think that a lot of depression and anxiety are often products of capitalist society. I'm not saying it's never anything else, and I'm certainly not saying it's invalid or not real. But considering that depression and anxiety increase as socioeconomic status decreases and the fact that a lot of people end up committing suicide due to financial strain and an inability to see a way out of a situation where we're working during all daylight hours and have no time to be social. That's only one example and there are countless more, not the least of which includes advertisements whose entire purpose is to make you feel shitty about yourself to sell products. Looking back at my own history I can say that these are the case for me, at least.  I don't know. I don't trust DSM culture nor pharmaceutical companies and I think it's counterproductive to declare anxiety and depression something innate when the science behind it is both new and compromised by financial interests (and also it's fucking stupid to tell a kid who gets bullied for years that they were born socially anxious, for example). I think we'd see significantly less depression and anxiety, and/or much less destructive cases of it, in a society where survival and community are a given and people could instead just work on making life actually cool. And it's frustrating that I'll probably be interpreted as wanting to erase the reality of mental illness because of that, but I get it. I'm not here for the 'get over it, it's all in your head, suck it up and go be a productive member of society' garbage either, that's also puritanical capitalist nonsense. I think while we're stuck here-- if an antidepressant helps you cope with our current hellscape better, that's awesome, you do you. Didn't do shit for me so I'm skeptical, but other people say they've saved their lives so what do I know.  Really liked/agreed with the video, if it wasn't obvious!

ContraPoints, you usually make great videos, but I have to disagree strongly with some of the conclusions that you've made here.  I'll focus mainly on the ADHD aspect, because I've spent my entire life struggling with this condition.  Adderall is certainly in the same class of chemicals as methamphetamine, but comparing Adderall to crystal meth is like comparing Advil to Fentanyl or a cup of coffee to cocaine.  Moreover, Adderall and Ritalin (which is in a different class of chemicals altogether) are both known to improve symptoms in children with ADHD.  These chemicals affect the brains of people with ADHD differently than neurotypical people.  When a person with ADHD takes these drugs, they don't feel like they're cranked up, as would be the experience of a neurotypical taking these drugs, but instead they just feel normal, like they can get through the day while actually being able to think clearly.  Sure, some of the studies that have shown their effectiveness over the last four decades have been industry-funded, but plenty have been funded by non-profit organizations and governments.    Your second error, and in my opinion the more serious one, is that you write off ADHD as merely a 'pattern of disordered thought or emotion' brought about only by 'children being bored' or due to emotional incompatibilities with the school system.  This is a major misunderstanding of the life experience of a person with this condition: many people with ADHD struggle in school despite actually wanting to do well, and in fact many of them are intellectually gifted and would be exceptional students were it not for their condition.  Perhaps it would be better to think of these not as 'bad students' but as students whose 'badness' happens to be treatable, and furthermore I feel like these students deserve the right to treat the condition that causes those academic weaknesses.  In my opinion it is just wrong to say that we should just tell these students that they need to give up their ambitions and not help them to seek treatment because we've decided that some people, by virtue of the accident of birth, get to have the privilege of having a brain that is capable of helping them realize their ambitions, and some don't.  I mean, even digressing from the issue of mental health for a second, don't people have a right to have the brain that they want to have?    Another objection I have to raise is against the implication that ADHD is only something that affects school performance.  It's not.  ADHD, especially when untreated, is associated with a higher mortality risk that lasts throughout the lifetime.  Yes, there is much to be said about the extent to which society overemphasizes arbitrary indicators of intelligence and the pressure that the education system puts on young people to center their whole lives on earning a high enough number so that they can get into another school and spend another four years doing it all over again, but I doubt that this will be any comfort to a teenager with untreated ADHD who's just landed in the ICU because he couldn't prevent his attention from lapsing while he was driving, or to a person who struggles to make friends because their inability to focus means they can't hold conversations.  Untreated ADHD is also a risk factor for depression, substance abuse, anxiety, and self-harm.  And I don't think that I should have to tell you that it has a neurological basis.  Over-diagnosis is also not an issue with ADHD, in fact, it's the other way around.  The majority of ADHD cases will not be diagnosed or treated, generally due to issues of economic class and gender.  Economic class because many poor people lack access to mental health services, and gender because ADHD is stereotypically seen as a 'boy's disease'. And on top of this, many people who demonstrably fit the profile don't seek treatment because they think that they're 'just lazy' or 'just stupid' or 'just not cut out for school', and dismissing the reality that ADHD is a disorder or minimizing the impact it has on people is doing a disservice to these individuals.  I'm sorry if my tone here came across as harsh, but I had to get that out there.  While I understand that you don't hold anti-psychiatry views, you should know that many of the points you make here are also some of the common talking points of the anti-psychiatry movement.

I want to start this by declaring my liking to your content. I really espouse your criticism of the Youtube atheist community and the whole anti social justice activism movement. But, this is a serious issue you are touching in the video, that requires expertise. I sympathize with your position; I understand that your lack of expertise in the field, and a personal bad experience have influenced your view about psychiatry, although there are some things that need to be clarified.  Claim 1: 'Most of the research of those drugs is funded by pharmaceutical companies with billions of dollars at stake' There are certain serious issues with Big Pharma, but most of the slander they get is based on conspiracy theories. Appealing to the motive of the scientists that research the subject is counter-productive. Do you really want to discredit valid evidence and arguments based on the author's motives?   Claim 2: 'Many of the most prescribed drugs barely do better than placebos' This is a factually wrong claim based on a handful of controversial (meaning not following standard consensus guidelines) peer reviewed publications that have been refuted. There are various studies showing that the efficacy of SSRIs is way better than placebos. Not to mention that a portion of the placebo effect can be attributed to a statistical regression (see: regression to the mean).  Claim 3: 'Psychiatry medicalizes ordinary human emotions and treats them as desease symptoms' and 'to call them desease is inevitably to pass a value judgement' Those overlap the field of philosophy, to which you are are more familiar than I am.  Classifying something as a desease or illness is simply a descriptive claim not a prescriptive one, therefore it does not pass a value judgement. You are the one making the value judgement, based on the contextual meaning of the word in other instances. The reality is that there are patterns that are really uncomfortable to a person, some of which are as maladaptive as to be considered an illness. I don't want to focus on that point a lot, as you only present it in the context of a cost-benefit analysis (see: below I deal with the side effect scare) and it can be open for debate.  Claim 4: 'Drugs on the market make you suicidal'  The side effects of SSRIs are highly exaggerated. I will only refute the suicide claim here, for practical reasons. The peer-reviewed scientific studies that showed an increase in suicide ideation were fundamentally flawed and have been refuted. The media and anti-psychiatry activists inflate those claims resulting in misconceptions. In fact there are clear scientific studies that show the opposite.  In reality, the manufactured scare resulted in a decreased drug prescription rate followed by a correlated increased suicide rate. (Reference PMID: PMC2799109)  As a closure I want to quote the statement of the American Psychiatric Association:  'Research has shown that serious neurobiological disorders such as schizophrenia reveal reproducible abnormalities of brain structure (such as ventricular enlargement) and function. Compelling evidence exists that disorders including schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and autism to name a few have a strong genetic component. Still, brain science has not advanced to the point where scientists or clinicians can point to readily discernible pathologic lesions or genetic abnormalities that in and of themselves serve as reliable or predictive biomarkers of a given mental disorder or mental disorders as a group. Ultimately, no gross anatomical lesion such as a tumor may ever be found; rather, mental disorders will likely be proven to represent disorders of intercellular communication; or of disrupted neural circuitry. Research already has elucidated some of the mechanisms of action of medications that are effective for depression, schizophrenia, anxiety, attention deficit, and cognitive disorders such as Alzheimer's disease. These medications clearly exert influence on specific neurotransmitters, naturally occurring brain chemicals that effect, or regulate, communication between neurons in regions of the brain that control mood, complex reasoning, anxiety, and cognition. In 1970, The Nobel Prize was awarded to Julius Axelrod, Ph.D., of the National Institute of Mental Health, for his discovery of how anti-depressant medications regulate the availability of neurotransmitters such as norepinephrine in the synapses, or gaps, between nerve cells.'   Even though you do issue a disclaimer I still think that this video is irresponsible and helps stigmatize mental patients and the field of psychiatry; you haven't researched the subject and only presented an one sided (your experience) view. I am not trying to sugar coat the field of psychiatry because there are some issues with overdiagnosis. Usually though, those issues, when presented outside the field of expertise result in misconceptions that can negatively affect human lives.

A thing I noticed with descriptions people gave of all sort of health problems they have had is that in some cases doctors have to sort of guess what the problem is until they stumble upon the right diagnosis, if they find out what exactly the problem is at all. My mother had back pains for a while and couldn't figure out what it was. After three doctors had prescribed different ways to deal with it, all with little effect, a fourth doctor, who happened to have a stronger background in the relevant medical field, managed to find out within minutes that the issue was probably a nerve in the upper spine. This was quickly confirmed and more appropriate treatment and accurate predictions of what would happen soon followed. Other people I know have had toilet problems for years until they found out what it was that they had kept eating that they were allergic for. Doctors aren't omniscient either and many people are misdiagnosed or under or overdiagnosed because of this. Apparently making the right diagnosis is just hard and sometimes due to bad luck our doctors don't know how to solve our problems or what our problems even are.   Besides that, the ease with which you apparently get medicated in America is a little concerning.

There's certainly a lot of wrong with psychiatry and psychology, just like with any thing. When I first tried to get some help for the debilitating despair I was experiencing and I went to a psychologist, it was terrible. After only a few visits, which were really stressful for me, I dropped trying to get help altogether and I became convinced that I couldn't get help. My oldest son was quasi-diagnosed with ADHD, and then and now, this just seemed like the dx du jour and bullshit. But later on a reasonable psychologist made the asperger's diagnosis and that had a clear basis in reality. I refused any psych meds though- there is no real understanding of the long term affects of these kinds of mind-altering substances used on developing brains. I have been in and out of a lot of nursing homes and long term care facilities, and if you ever meet a person who has been taking hard core drugs for a long time.....its pretty fucking awful. And in my son's case, I am very sympathetic to the idea of someone just not being 'neurotypical', and that may not always be a bad thing. Its not like neurotypical human behavior is so endlessly fabulous.  For me, I likely would not be alive today without psychology. My 'major depressive disorder recurrent with obsessional tendencies' was like a little gremlin living in my head talking about the beauty of death and the ugliness of me, and sometimes the little fucker sounds pretty reasonable. The zoloft takes enough of the edge off that I can deal with it. I've been on other stuff which helped but had too many side effects.  To me a lot of it revolves around what is really affecting you and your life, and what trade-offs you are willing to make to deal with it. This isn't actually so far off from other health issues. If you have cancer or heart disease or a bone problem or whatever, there are usually a range of options open to you and you have to decide what you will or won't do. And drug companies would like you to just be non-stop medicated, but you gotta do what is right for you.  Now, while I of course agree that you are very brave, indeed, in making this video and it was as brilliant as usual, I must say that there are better ways to cook octopus. A slow braise in wine, a little olive oil and garlic, until tender.......just saying.
