I think this variation on humanity as it has existed here on Spaceship:Earth has got a severely flawed, dangerous, and completely slavishly pathetic understanding of emotions. That they are referred to as emotion's', as in plural, while the 'intellect' enjoys a unified conception is telling. The thinking seems to be that emotions that effect the output of a human should be policed and emotions that don't are but sleeping dogs that should not be disturbed. The ability to swallow up and un-identify with our emotions was and is considered a strength, such as when Tony Soprano bemoaned the fading glory of such types as Gary Cooper, 'The Strong Silent Type'. Just at the point when true psychological understanding and ownership stood its most potential possibility for freedom, after the likes of Freud, Jung, and my personal fave, Erich Fromm, the disease industry ( something I consider akin to a policing agency) has given us the ability to avoid ourselves to the very end, by drugging us in such a way that we aren't so much as healed or fixed, but rather nullified by something that strips our identity away. It's awful. I consider myself a cynical optimist, Critical but frankly, happier than most, I think. I have rage in my soul and a very deep capacity to love. How much would i have any of that had I accepted the answer my Psychologists and Psychiatrists prescribed: that the best means for coping with barely punishable parental mental and physical abuse was a 150mg of thorazine and 4mg of Stelazine a day? That's what they gave me. I quit them after a year, and instead learned fashionably acceptable forms of manipulation to end the abuse and get as far from home as possible. The rest was self exploration and a refusal to accept easy answers or even answers at all. The entire disease industry runs on the notion that you will do anything to have an answer, something to believe, so as to stop all that pesky brain thinking. Nietzsche had some words on the subject when he suggested we are stunted by a will to an end. About 50 years ago (this was before I was born) my Grandfather committed suicide for no apparent reason.  No every talked about it and for the most part my family took an active role in ignoring the incident as well as any other mental illness in the family.  My aunt on the other side of the family has been dealing with bipolar depression for most of her life, she falls prey to moods swings as well as long bouts of despair, for the longest time her siblings (including my father) chose to deal with this by getting angry at her for 'not getting her life together' and taking 'tough love' approach, which amount to saying insensitive to her in the hope she would somehow fix herself in the method of a stoic.  It got so bad that she practically became a shut-in who was cut off from all of the family but myself. Now this is where I come in, slowly over the course of my academic life I began to develop violent mood swings, short periods of euphoria followed by long (weeks, months, even seasons) periods of depression and total draining of energy, so that my body ached all the time, not to mention constant feeling of anxiety with in turn lead to insomnia, and eventually daily anxiety attacks, where my brain would begin to spin like a wheel and sense would overload, and I would be overcome with the sense that everything was irrevocably wrong.  Now all this did not happen at once, and it more or less built up over time, but any time I tried to ask for help from my family I was almost always told something like, 'you should go to bed earlier', or if I brought up my Aunt or Grandfather, my parents would tell never tell anyone about them: 'she has a mental disorder; you don't have that; don't let people think that.'  After seven years of taking the stoic approach, with the belief that I merely needed to buckle down and work harder, and that all of this despair would go away if I merely found a purpose, I reached a point in which I could go no further.  My body had no strength left, I found myself sobbing uncontrollably, and I was experiencing four or five anxiety attacks in a row daily.  My mother, herself brought to tears (she the daughter of my grandfather who had shot himself 50 years ago), finally took my to a psychiatrist. It is two year later, I no longer suffer any of the symptoms of Bipolar disorder, and my Doctor is also slowly reducing my medication.  It is no exaggeration that if I lived in another century I would have no doubt killed myself, and physics of the mind saved my life. This is other extreme, to ignore all the problems of the mind, and I barely survived it.

Look, as much as I usually like your videos, speaking as somebody on the autism spectrum who's known quite a few people with mental health issues, this video is irresponsible and disgusting and you should feel goddamn ashamed to put it out.   Like, yeah that 'moody' teenager could just be 'moody,' but the dismissal of mental health problems at that age as just a subjective state of mind not only can lead to letting issues fester that can fuck you up for life and deny young people the language to talk about their problems, but it leads to erasure of the mental health experience and leaves people lost wondering 'Is this all my fault?' I know multiple people who almost died due to that exact sort of dismissal of their mental health issues on the psychosis spectrum at that age, and I know they wouldn't appreciate this garbage in the slightest.  No matter how well intentioned, this rhetoric of over-diagnosis and 'It's all just a state of mind maaaaaaaan' leads to erasure of neuroatypicality and mental health issues, and to gatekeeping of treatment because 'how do you know you aren't lying'. It leads to people being unable to speak about their neurological differences and getting help for them because the language they use is dismissed as being 'lazy' or denying 'responsibility,' the most notable example of which is executive dysfunction. And I am so goddamn sick of this hippie garbage about how we should all just goddamn erase the  neuroatypicality just because some snooty little hellicopter parents got a diagnosis wrong once or couldn't come up with a plan that works for you  I'm sick of the rhetoric of neurodiversity and self-determination being hijacked by neurotypicals like you, who have zero idea of what you're talking about but have only experienced the mental healthcare system as a bourgie luxury than a VITAL NEED as so many of us do, for the purposes of erasure and vague hippie nonsense that leads to gatekeeping, and rhetoric like yours has hurt so many of my friends. TL/DR, this video is disgusting and ableist and I hate it.

i was also diagnosed ADD in the early 2000s as an elementary schooler. took ritalin it on and off for a while but was more 'off' it by high school. in college i had severe depression and was self harming and making suicide attempts. took two and a half more years of psychiatry and counseling to find a medication that worked for me. psychiatric medicine (at least for things like depression) seem to be a big game of guess and check until you happen upon something that works. to me it seems like the only real way to get decent results from medication is if the individual in question is knowledgeable about the prescriptions they are taking and take a very active self-advocacy role in their treatment. unfortunately most people who need psychiatric care are not really in a position to do that very effectively. i think this is why it seems like there is an over-diagnosis and under-diagnosis problem simultaneously.  i only really recommend going the route of medical psychiatric care for people who have very severe symptoms that are either unbearable or put your own health or the safety of others at risk. years or more of patience and the experience of mild to severe side effects are more or less inevitable, but can be extremely worth it. counseling though is chill and less terrible to get through if you are able to find a good counselor and can afford it.

I've had mostly positive experiences with psychiatry (except for the first therapist I ever saw who was a fucking BITCH). Medication is a bit different. As someone with bipolar disorder and severe anxiety (not a misdiagnosis, thankfully), some meds have helped me, like risperidol (or however you spell it) and gabapentin for my anxiety, and my current psychiatrist is wonderful. But then I've had negative experiences too. Lithium, while it did help with mania, just kind of made me feel like I was...I don't know. I guess a subdued version of myself? And then I was briefly on Zoloft, and seriously FUCK ZOLOFT. I know that it's helped some people, which is great, but good god it made me a thousand times worse, and because of that I NEVER EVER want to be on any type of anti-depressant ever again. I've been off any type of medication for over a year now, and I feel generally okay. Sure, I still get depressive episodes, I still have manic episodes. I wish I wasn't bipolar. But it's more or less who I am. Sometimes it gets to me, other times I can manage it. I mean, I'm still alive and surprisingly have not had a mental breakdown this year and I'm almost one year clean of self-harm (something I've struggled with for over a decade). I was able to do all that without meds. I'm not anti-psychiatry and certainly not anti-meds, I know that for many people it's absolutely necessary and I respect that. But it is certainly possible to live with a mental illness and be okay and otherwise functioning without medication. And I'm always skeptical and cautious of teens being put on stuff like zoloft or lithium or anti-psychotics with potentially dangerous side effects. I don't know. I feel like you can certainly live with things like depression or anxiety without meds as long as it doesn't become a major hinderance in your life to the point where you can't function or you're suicidal (but that goes without saying). I don't know where I'm going with this comment. Short version: I pretty much agree with everything you say and I think you're great and hilarious.

I have to say I do agree with you, way too many people are over-diagnosed with way too many things, both in mental health and in physical health issues. Trying to medicate people so that they will fit into some mandated system is generally not helpful to the person being medicated, just the people around them. Trying to medicate away emotions is not helpful to the person being medicated, just the people around them. Finding medication that treats a neural-chemical imbalance, is extremely helpful to the person needing the medication, but maybe not as much so to the people around them. The easy way out is often easier than facing the actual problem. Unfortunately, taking the easy way out usually causes more problems for everyone in the long run.    Personally, I've been on and off medication for more than three decades. I have severe issues without the medication, but I managed to cope without it for a long time.  I wanted to die at least once a day, with or without the medication, but I had children I could not leave. So I just kept breathing, one breath at a time some days.  Being emotionally unstable and self-destructive is one thing, but when I lost the ability to hold a thought long enough to finish a sentence, that was not something I could breathe my way thru. It's taken a lot of tries, most of which had severe side effects, but I finally found what works for me. I have some peace inside my brain, and I can hold onto thoughts long enough to express them now. I still can't leave my house, but I am not nearly as interested in leaving life.
I'm in no way an authority on the subject either, but bruce levine talks about authoritarianism and the DSM in a unique way. A different perspective to consider.

Quick thoughts on diagnosis from a clinical mental health counselor- when deciding if a behavior (emotional state) is diagnosable the two key questions are 1. Is it statistically abnormal in your culture/community? 2. Does it cause you distress that interferes with your life? If you are feeling distressed about some aspects of your behaviors or emotions engage in preventative care- work with a licensed therapist or counselor before meeting with a professional (psychiatrist, psychiatric nurse etc) who's role is to treat these concerns with mediation.

On the one hand, it sucks when people are over diagnosed. But on the other hand, other people are in some ways UNDER diagnosed. I myself was just considered to be 'retarded' up until I was about 15, and the proper way to address this was with derision and mockery. Around the age of 15 I was finally diagnosed with autism, and got the help I needed. After this point, I began to flourish in school and in my social life, whereas I had previously struggled. Similarly, my parents just thought that I listened to too much angry music and played too many violent video games until I was about 14, when I was diagnosed with depression. After this, I was put on medication, and (for the most part) stopped trying to kill myself.   I find that a lot of this comes down to both race and class. I myself am of the lower/working class, and as such received my diagnosis of 'retardation' from my pediatrician. Even when I did finally see a real psychiatrist, he turned out to be unlicensed. Most of my psychiatrists have been similarly flawed. I would also be remiss not to mention the role race plays in all of this-specifically in the public school system. While the schools I've attended have all been majority white, they have been somewhat diverse. And of the sizeable black and latinx population, almost all of them have been placed in special ed. This is very interesting. On the one hand, students that are not disabled or mentally ill get placed in special ed due to poor performance caused by outside sources (such as the lead paint you touched upon in your last video). On the other hand, some of these students are in some way disabled. Several of them are almost certainly autistic, but absolutely NONE of them are diagnosed, which prevents them from receiving the right sort of assistance.  I also feel like it's a poor representation of the psychiatric field to discuss whether or not depression and other maladies would count as 'diseases'. Again, drawing from personal experience, I do not consider either my autism or my depression to be 'diseases'. I consider my autism to be a disability, and believe that I should be given extra accommodation and care for it, in much the same way that somebody with broken legs would be provided with a wheelchair. As far as depression goes, I don't know what I would call it. And while some of my depression is caused by outside forces, it's much higher than it rationally should be. No amount of fixing my problems will end it, and I need my medication to function properly.  But that's just my two cents.

I was given drugs for ADHD and depression when I was young but I stopped taking them and refused to do so... until I had no other choice.  My gender dysphoria spiked at a certain point and I had no way to deal with it because I refused to accept it, which fueled my depression to a crippling extent. Yup, I've had a similar thing happen to me. When I was a junior in high school I went to a school psychologist because I had been compulsively creating stories and fictional narratives which I obsessed over to the point that I couldn't focus on anything else. She said (perhaps rightly) that it resembled OCD to her and she recommended that I see a psychiatrist. The psychiatrist talked to me for about six minutes and then casually declared 'Yup, OCD. Here's a prescription for sertraline'. The sertraline proved to have a weird effect on me, namely I had a few short hypomanic episodes (basically I was restless, nervous, couldn't stop talking or pacing for a couple of hours) as I was taking the pills. I told the psychiatrist that at my next visit and she casually said 'Well, you're bipolar. Here's a prescription for anti-seizure medication.' I took those pills for a couple of weeks uring which I couldn't even sit upright in a chair because they were messing with my brain chemistry apparently. Then my mom took me to another psychiatrist, who actually talked to me for, like, more than 10 minutes, and told me that I was perfectly fine  a well-structured psychotherapy should be enough to deal with my compulsion. So, yeah, psychiatrists are a pretty mixed bag.   Plus, being a high-schooler while going through that was pretty shitty. I have a bit of a dramatic personality (not drama loving, just enthusiastic and displaying a variety of emotions), and when I was a senior one of my teachers joked about me being bipolar when she saw me sad shortly after being cheerful and happy. I said to her 'You know, you have quite an intuition, because I actually was diagnosed with that at one point.' I expected her to get uneasy about making fun of me, but instead she started doing it more often. After my graduation I sent her a long e-mail detailing my story and asking her not to make fun of mentally ill students in the future. She never responded.

Within every cynic is a disappointed idealist.  I think the reason I'm more comfortable in the absence of happiness is that I've been conditioned to see it less as a genuine state of mind and more as a desperate grab at distraction from the nuanced peril of reality.  I trust only in disappointment, and that's why I expect to become a career criminal within my lifetime.

It is unfathomably bizarre to me that anyone would think that the solution to a behavioural problem could possibly be: medication, and even more bizarre to think that this reasoning is widely accepted. I'm not saying this hasn't/ can't/ won't help people; just that due to my own bubble, it seems extraterrestrial.

In my particular case, my parents also sent me to psychiatrists and therapists when I was very young and physically immature. I wasn't really diagnosed with much of anything oddly enough, even though my behavior was very much beyond what my parents, teachers and peers thought was 'typical.' My brother was and is diagnosed for ADHD and I have no idea if he really does have an issue like this, or if the drugs that he constantly does not take help him in any significant way.   Now, after spending months with a therapist I was diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder, a case of hypersensitivity rather extreme (both in a physical and emotional sense) and mild body dysphoria due to me being trans. Thanks to my involvement in psychiatry today my life is significant better and manageable, allowing me to feel confident in going to college soon and becoming independent - plus the drugs anyway but Zoloft has done a good wonder for me, as far as I can tell.   I will mention for the sake of consideration that in elementary school, I would consistently bang my head against desks and walls if I remotely failed anything, would cry and react horribly if someone said a word I had played in scrabble was incorrect in any way and would sob in a corner during recess on occasion due to everything being 'too loud' and/or someone said something remotely mean or rude to me, plus other nice things. Needless to say, therapy and psychiatry when I was younger did jack-shit, and it really shouldn't have done anything anyway in my mind: treating emotionally immature kids like people with issues and diseases as if they're fully grown adults is not a good way to go about such issues. Not that I have a better answer off the top of my head, but I've always hated the industry for it.

Most psychiatric diagnoses isolate the person from the environment. They get the whole framing the problems wrong. They ask 'why isn't this person well-adjusted to their situation?' when they should also ask 'Wait, could a shitty situation be at the root of this person's distress?'  So that's a great point about the school system. You could extend that to hierarchical society in general. Systems try to mould individuals so as to be useful, not to realise themselves as persons. In other words, psychological problems are much more of a social problem than a private problem. We need to make the society better at the macro level in order to get mentally healthier people at the micro level.  Yet we make pathologies out of behaviour which signals that something's grossly wrong with what the system expects from them.  I know this is a cliche quote from Krishnamurti, but ... 'It's no sign of good health to be well-adjusted to a sick society'.

1. How was the octopus after frying it?  2. I don't fully agree with *everything* in this video (most of it, though), but I'm on board being skeptical of for-profit medicine. Something we should probably start to recognize: every business model revolves around bubbles for infinite growth. Where people do actually live with what I would call a disease (schizophrenia, borderline personality disorder, etc.). A lot of less-serious stuff is very over-diagnosed for the sake of money.  But even the less serious things like depression can get more serious, and if medicine helps, 'disease' is appropriate. The big thing, though, is everything has to be overconsumed for today's models to operate to shareholder/board satisfaction. Because a company has to be growing to be considered healthy, a company based on health is interested in treating more people. So people have to be divided and labeled in a manner that encourages more consumption.  What better way than blurring the lines between serious conditions and stuff being more emotionally intelligent would fix. Learning to fish creates independence, being given a fish creates dependence. Now, the issue with this is that it's often taken as an attack on people who legitimately need medication. And it also can reinforce people who say 'medication is bad.' So it's really tricky, because medication isn't bad. But the pharma industry is very, very bad - because again, it's about putting you in an information vacuum (individual bubbles) and profiting.
